info.content:
Learning from our experiences three days earlier, we went early to Windsor, Daddy even researched the car park to go to! Saddo.

Strangely this world landmark which is less than 10 miles away has never been visited by us. Luckily the free tickets meant we saved £51 on admission. It was an airport styled admission, with scanners and friskers!

We entered and was bowled over by how nice the castle stone, design and grounds looked. We looked at the dolls house and the state rooms. Daddy's favourite was the Crimson Room. We spoke to one of the staff and he told some interesting facts and stories.

The state appertments

Ben standing to attention

Family shot

Henry VIII Gateway

Daddy and Katie outside St Georges Chapel

Lower Ward grounds

Daddy and Katie again

Cheeky Jess

In the evening we went to the Elders house to see the new year in. Char and Loz were also in attendance to play games and eat food!

Mikey going for it in the Cereal Box challenge

title.value: Windsor Castle, Elder's for New Years

info.content:
In the morning Jessica went with Aimee Huggets to Bracknell Ice Rink and skated for a couple of hours before moving onto the Harvester for some lunch. Very lucky girl. Aimee's Daddy (who is a good skater) said Jessica had good balance and would make a good skater. It was nice for Jessica to catch up with her old best friend. Jessica is going to start Gymnastics up again with Aimee. Good times.

Meanwhile the rest of us went for a bike ride on our new bikes, only Daddy with his old bike! Anyway there was a lot of moaning especially from Miss Kitkat G.

Downhill in the woods

The route went through the woods by St Catherines Road, up to Deepcut, then past our old house, then through the army grounds down to the Basingstoke Canal and back home. It was good to get the cobwebs blown away.

Back home along the Basingstoke Canal

title.value: Family Bike Ride + Jessica Ice Skating

info.content:
Mummy had organised a load of us to go and see Aladdin at Camberley Theatre. It was very entertaining.

Aladdin

Well we had a bit of a nightmare journey to Windsor after lunch time. The traffic was bad and there were no parking spaces at all. In the end Daddy dropped us of all in town and had to go over the Thames into Datchett, park then run / walk into Windsor.

The reason for Windsor is that we were kindly given free tickets for a tour of the castle. However, the queue was huge. So we decided to abort, and spend some Christmas money instead in the shops.

Bye Bye Windsor Castle

We slept over at Ma Ma's, Daddy waking early to do the Malling parkrun. After, we ventured home to finally have a moment to ourselves and start playing with some of the toys we got and prepare for this afternoons family party.

We had many of the Barnett side of family and some of the Gay's also. It was an evening of games, boys versus girls.

Boxing Day games

Give Us A Clue

Us kiddies were up all night. In the end Mummy and Daddy said 6am was the start.... and 6am on the dot the lights went on and we were invited into Ben's room to see what us three had got.

6am start. Opening Father Christmas's delivery

Ben's main presents were: Man Utd training top, trainers and a bike.

Katie's were: ???? and a bike.

Jessica got: Lego Friends Hotel and a scooter.

One at a time opening Father Christmas's presents

Next up were Mummy and Daddy's from each other. Mummy got a new pair of Converse trainers, Rush 2 perfume, a top, a calendar, a Donna Lewis CD. Daddy got a running magazine, two packets of crisps, a running light to put on his arm.

Next was a small spot of breakfast before opening presents from friends under our own tree.

Friends presents

We then packed up to go to the Fars for breakfast. Mummy popped off to church.

Family Shot

About 11:30-ish we left for Istead Rise for the next part of our Christmas. The Weston's. Here the Elders, Charlotte and Loz also came. This year we all had the turkey roast at the same time and Daddy managed to eat it in good time for once. We then went out for a walk around the estate and bothered some of Ma ma's friends.

A load of Turkey

A civilized bunch of Turkeys

When we returned we played this Russian Roulette type game, but with a creamed pie splatted in your face instead of a bullet in the head. That was fun.

We opened loads of presents, played more games before finally going to bed.... letting the adults then open their presents from each other and family.

Ben opening presents sporting his new Man Utd top

Katie in new pyjamas

Jessica opening presents in her new coat

Tobot the dude

Jessica showing off presents

Daddy worked from home in the morning whilst helping Katie make bread for a late Farfar present.... another game of Formula One also.

4pm and it was around to the Fars, plus Auntie Susan and Graham. We all say this is the most Christmassy feeling we get. First up was a game of Coppit which is traditional now. There was some fierce attacking.

Copp That

We had Roast Pork, sausages, caramelized potatoes and riselamange. Yum. Some could barely move. We went off to complete Farfar's Treasure Hunt around Richmond Close and surrounding areas.... there was some real treasure in the form of pounds sterling!

Next up was the dice game. Similar to a Chinese Auction. The lottery tickets were top of the hit list for most.

Dice Game

Then the main event, present time! There were 3 helpers willing to sort, manage and deliver presents one at a time. Ben received a Man Utd magazine, Man Utd clock, book and a Macarno car set as well as a football goal for the back garden and Match Attax cards. Katie received a lovely outfit, a fashion book as well as some smellies.

Wow going on past 9pm, it was time to leave and prepare some milk, a mince pie for Father Christmas as well as some reindeer food outside the front door. Mummy went to midnight mass..... and Father Christmas delivered really, very, carefully!

Present Time
We met up with the Burrows, minus the Dad's and played in the mud and rain at Box Hill.

After saying goodbye to Katie's friends, we went to church, then had roast pork.

Then we had a round of baking. Katie went to the Fars to bake some Christmas biscuits and put the finishing touches on their Christmas tree.

Meanwhile Ben and Jessica were testing their icing and sculptor skills. Jessica showed some flair.

Later in the afternoon Mummy went to church for a carol service, whilst Farfar came around and joined us in Daddy's childhood board game called Formula 1. We had a laugh. Farfar won, Daddy came last. That ended a weekend where we played the game about 5 times!

Formula One

Formula One Board

Katie had Grace, Natasha and Nina over for a sleepover.

Katie and friends

We also played more Formula 1, which is deffo very popular at the moment.

In the morning Daddy, Jessica and Ben went to parkrun. The weather was very mild, about 9 degrees. Ben and Jessica did very well and completed a lap. After Daddy went down the café to celebrate Maddie's 25 volunteers landmark, and Sarah's 50th parkrun. Meanwhile the Fars took us children down the sweet shop and treated us. Mummy went with the church and sung carols at two old people's homes down St. Catherine's Road.

Parkrunners

In the afternoon Daddy and Ben went to watch the new Star Wars film - The Force Awakens, at the new Farnborough cinema. Ben was so sweet and really loved the film. He said during it. 'It was heaven watching Star Wars in the cinema, with sweets and with you Dad.' Sickly I know, but it made Daddy feel good. Ben's rated this as his number 1 movie, in front of; Lego Movie, James Bond - Spectre and Harry Potter.

Star Wars

In the later afternoon / evening, Katie had Natasha, Grace and Nina over for a sleepover. They were relatively quiet, making Christmas biscuits, watching films and chatting. Reportedly some didn't goto sleep till gone 3am!

title.value: Parkrun, Carol Singing, Star Wars - The Force Awakens, Katie's Sleepover

info.content:
Our annual Christmas Meal this year was at Toby Carvery in Aldershot. Exotic I know. Jessica and Ben loved the drinks machine. Free refills and could make flavoured Coke's. We had a strawberry and a cherry flavour at least

Toby Carvery Christmas Meal

A busy morning with Ben doing his first lap of parkrun in 7 months. It was good to Ben back on the new course. Later the boys joined the Elders to watch Joey play a Cup Final at Frimley Lodge park which he won.

Joey in his cup final

Mummy took us girls, Lily and Toby down to the Baptist church to make Christmas craft.

Daddy went to the Frimley Flyers lunch at the Ely. He came 4th out of 14. It was good to see us all there.

Flyers

The Golden Envelope

title.value: Church Craft - Joey Cup Final - Frimley Flyers Lunch

info.content:
Daddy went out with Michael, Millie, Kumar and Rob. All CNL colleagues. It was good to catch up.

Meanwhile, we went puzzle crazy for a bit.

Puzzling

Mummy and Daddy went to see Jessica in her school nativity play. Jessica was in the choir. She thought it unfair that she didn't have the chance to play more prominent role as she was in the library reading when they picked the actors.

At the back in the choir

We had the West's stay over and there was still a fair amount of clearing up to be done from last night's party. So most of the morning was taken up with that and of course a trip to church.

In the afternoon Daddy went down to Frimley Lodge Park and helped on the Scout tent where they were selling refreshments, highlights being camp doughnuts which is a glorified deep fried, jam sandwich covered in sugar and custard infused hot chocolate which tasted very nice.

Parkrun in the morning, and after yesterday's physio meeting, Ben is going to start light running. So the boy ran the 1km from home to parkrun. The Frimley Flyers were pleased to see the young man.

Straight after we went over to the Elders. Lily requested that Mummy run the birthday party in terms of games. Ben weighed in with a music quiz and sounds like everything went very well. Importantly Lily was pleased. Apparently one of the children mentioned to their mum that wanted 'a party planner at their party'! High praise indeed.

Lily's Birthday Party Lunch

In the evening it was the annual Gays Christmas Party. This year we had the Elders, Sanders, Wests, Charlie and Loz in attendance. Some of the ladies started on the Prosecco early and felt a little worse for wear as the evening wore on. The games started quick and rolled off quick. Katie ran the 'titles' game. This year we had a slight twist with individual challenges dotted in between rounds. We learnt that Karen is more agile than Daddy, Josh is stronger than Charlotte, Mummy is more logical than E'ster (work that one out), Bazza can fit more marshmallows in his mouth than Charlotte and Loz can withstand the electrocution test better than Julie!

Looking at awe at Charlie's marshmallow exploits

Perhaps the biggest shock of the evening was Ellie losing out on Spoons at the quatre-final stage. Daddy took the honours there! Overall the boys team won (again!).

Daddy and Bazza were the last men standing at 3am! Josh took advantage of Julie's state and started drawing on her face! Katie was scared off mummy because she was a little tipsy and crashed out early.

Josh handing out flour (strength test)

Julie looking like she's enjoying being electrocuted

For the past month Daddy has been making a desk for the computer in the conservatory. It's been made out of palettes left from the builders.

Palette Table
We went to the Arena in the afternoon and played on the big inflatable in the swimming pool.

After parkrun we went to Badshot Lea garden centre to see Father Christmas come on his horse drawn sleigh. We then went out the back to see a couple of his reindeers crazing on the stone!

Meeting Rudolph

The bolier had packed up earlier in the week. With the condition of the boiler and cost of the repair it was decided we should get a new one.... a Bosch Worcester Greenstar. We're £2250 lighter in the pocket! Labour £140 per hour. Extortionate.

Mummy and Daddy went out in the evening to the Thai Terrace for the Net Evidence Christmas Do. We spent most of our time with Richard and Julie, the CEO and his wife. Mummy was great, didn't come across too nervous at all. Daddy was proud of her.

title.value: Boiler replaced and Net Evidence Meal

info.content:
We went over to the Fars for tea, make some craft, play the computer and see the latest with the decorating.

Farfar with us

The battle of Devil's Punchbowl. So our family walks had dried up a bit lately so we decided to go out and have some nice family time..... well that backfired! There were 3 of us who were less than enthusiastic, resistance was rife and 2 who ploughed on regardless. Jessica moaned, more because the others were complaining. Then we realised her boots were rubbing against her skin, so bless her the walk was hurting her. Katie remained quiet and moody mostly. Then came Benjamin who refused to dress properly for the low temperatures. His shorts, Man Utd shirt and sweater are a constant fixture no matter the occasion, be it church, being at home or going out on a cold day! He definitely cut off his nose to spite his face. He was shivering at points. Daddy was even carrying his coat around and at one point threw it at him to put on. He walked passed it. He complained, moaned, came out with every excuse under the sun for not participating. That boy!

Devils

Matters were not improved when we lost our way a bit. An hour and a half later it was all over. We apologised to Mummy and Daddy on the way home.

Steve popped over with the new addition to the family; Molly Barnett

Molly Barnett

In the morning Daddy went on a 40 mile bike ride with Bob and Michael from Weybourne to Lasham and Frensham. Daddy struggled a bit towards the end, but enjoyed himself.

Cycle Route

Daddy went to collect Katie bike, £30 second hand. A bit more rusty than originally hoped, not too sure if Katie will accept it with open arms. Sunday lunch on Mummy's Slimmers World menu. Still tasted nice. Mummy reckons she's lost a few pounds in the first week of her new diet regime.

The afternoon was spent with clearing the leaves from the front and back garden, doing homework, daddy continuing with his pallet desk and watching Stormbreaker, Alex Ryder film. Jessica continues to have a nasty cough and sough throat.

Daddy parkrunned in the morning followed by a trip to the cafe. Us girls went over to Gravesend for a sleepover with Summer and Alice. Aunty Karen took us into Bluewater to do some Christmas Shopping. Somehow Katie had £30 to spend all donated via eyelid actions!

Meanwhile in the afternoon Daddy and Ben started programming in C#. A football management game was born. Ben soaked it all up and was pretty enthusiastic. They started a Windows Form Application and made a couple of the initial screens up.

In the evening Denmark played Sweden in an important knock out qualifier for next years qualifiers. Denmark lost 2-1, although there is the second leg still to come.

Joey came over and played with Ben until gone 3am! They get on so well, playing Fifa and watching films.

In the morning we all went to St Andrews to commemorate Remembrance Day. We all went in our Brownies, Cubs and Guides whilst Daddy turned up in his suit.

After the church service we met with the Fars and went to the Scout hut where Ben not only got invested into Warburton Scout group, but also received a certificate for his Silver Award. Basically he's earned enough badge to get an award. We were proud of him.

Ben earning his Silver Award

In the afternoon we had a family game of Risk. Yes a photo where we were all laughing at a game of Risk and not falling out with each other.... Mummy was first to crack. 'I hate this stupid game' I think were here words. Daddy won!

Risky laughing

title.value: Remembrance Service, Ben's Silver Award and promotion to Scout

info.content:
Daddy didn't parkrun this week. He wasn't feeling too well! The weather was also terrible so we played at home.

We went over to the Elders. First time Daddy has seen them for 2 months. It was good to catch up and see the continued decoration work.

In the evening we went over to Grove Fireworks with the Fars and Natasha. So nice to see a good bonfire.

Natasha and Katie watched films until late into the night. Natasha stayed over.

We sparkled in the back garden

Mummy started Slimmers Club. She is the same weight as Daddy, about 68kg.

Mummy went off with the other Grandchildren to Penny Hill Park to treat Grandma to afternoon tea. It so happened that the recent World Rugby Union Champions were also in the same bar / room as Mummy. Very exciting. However, none of them had the courage to go and at least ask for an autograph.

Champion All Blacks enjoying a drink

Meanwhile, Daddy, Katie, Ben and Jessica all went over to Essex for the traditional trip to the Firecracker Banger event. This year we had Ma Ma and Pop Pop, Howard and Susan watching with us. It was a really foggy day, and once daylight ended we couldn't see the far end of the track just because of the gloom. However, the racing was entertaining. Not as many bangers it felt this year. The fireworks display was interesting in the thick fog. Still we all had a good time. Same again next year.

50 year old Jag with Ben, Howard and Pop Pop

Typical Jessa Pose

In the morning we returned from Ma ma and Pop Pop's. Daddy was running at parkrun. He was asked to be a pacer at 24 minutes, which should have been ok, expect as a Halloween trick the course was ran backwards, which meant Daddy was at the back and had to fight his way to a 23:55. At 11am, we went Pumpkin Carving at Frimley Lodge for a couple of hours. We carved pumpkins and made old boot plant pots which now sit proudly by the front door!

Daddy went off to visit Steve and Joyce before heading towards the Madjseki stadium with Phil to watch Reading draw with top of the table Brighton in an entertaining Championship match.

In the afternoon, Ben went bowling for Oliver's 11th birthday in Camberley. Later we went to St. Peter's for the Light Party. Daddy picked up Ben, Katie and Natasha and went Trick or Treating around the Dettingen estate. The block of 8 houses we used to live in did not seem to partake in festivities. However, there were enough homes with pumpkins and decorations outside to tap on their doors. We collected loads of sweets! A busy day.

Trick or Treaters?

title.value: Pumpkin Carving, Olivers 11th Birthday, Light Party, Trick or Treat, Reading v Brighton

info.content:
Overnight stay with Ma Ma and Pop Pop. We went to spend the day with the Teale's, including a trip to Broaditch Farm. Unfortunately the tractor ride was fully booked out - still we had a good time and ended up in the haunted house.

Summer and Alice with Katie and Jess

Meanwhile Ben went out with Ma Ma and Joey to watch the new James Bond film, Spectre.

We went to Cobtree Manor Park near Maidstone with the Burrows and Morley clans. It was nice to meet up.

Looking over Fi's 40th birthday book

title.value: Cobtree Manor Park with Fiona and Helen

info.content:
Joey Harris came over to play with Ben, whilst Jessica had invited Imogen and Emma for a sleepover.

Daddy's stress levels were quite high as he looked after things in the evening. There was make up on Jessica's white carpet, desk and chair. They were jumping off the sofa on to a mattress and just causing all round mess. Fortunately Katie was there to act as a mediator. She was brilliant. Despite all this, Jessica and friends had a great time staying up late watching films.

We woke a bit late, had our big breakfast and said goodbye to our hotel. A northward journey of about an hour. We parked up around the corner from the pleasure beach. We couldn't believe how long the queues were to get in. Still mystified as to why. 45 minutes. There were lots of staff on the tills.

First ride was on the sedate rocket ride. One of the oldest on the park. Ben and Daddy went on the Ice Blast, the ride that shoots you up 210 feet vertically at an inordinate velocity. Ben was scared. You could tell by the noises that came from him. They weren't from a cool, 'I can handle dad', Ben. We then went on the Grand National, a favourite of mum's. We then split, mummy, daddy and Ben went on Infusion, the vampire equivalent ride, that went upside down and very fast. It felt as if we were in one roll into the next. Again Ben loved it. Not as scary add he thought. Katie and Jess went too Nickelodeon World and went on a Blue Flyer coaster. Then it was time for the Big One.... or Pepsi Max in old money. Daddy was worried. Speed is what does him in these days. Ben sat on the back car with him, with mummy just in front. The long climb up is the worst, followed by arching the summit, the 90 degree twist, then woosshhh. 85mph. Best ride off the day.

So many more rides as the queues were reasonably short. Avalanche, a coaster seemingly not running on rails, a toboggan ride. Revolution, loop the loop backwards and the disappointing Red Arrows Skyforce ride, where you could control when you went upside down..... except Ben's arms were not long enough to control this! The girls got soaked on the watery Valhalla ride. They were scared stiff as by this time darkness had fallen and the ride was in pitch black going down into water! We ended about 6pm, headed to the nearest chip shop, sort of looked at the illuminations. The traffic awful to drive down the seafront so decided to make the 5 hour journey home. Some had work in the morning!

Overall a great family trip away which we all loved... who wouldn't?

In front of Valhala

Katie on the rocket

Queueing for Infusion

Ben and The Big One

Coasters in the dark

Katie in the illuminations

The girls were dropped off at the Trafford Centre, the shopping bit. They were there to spend a bit of money on girls things!

Meanwhile the boys went to Old Trafford for a booked in tour of the stadium and a peek around the museum. First a walk around the ground and get loads of photos. We got told off when Ben climbed and sat on the Charlton, Law, Best statue. Still we got a photo. The Reds café was awesome, just because each of the back of the chairs had a Man Utd legend on the back. Small things and all that. No Schmichael or Olsen though!

We were too engrossed in the museum and missed our tour time slot! Fortunately we got on the next one, ten minutes later. We started by going up in to the Alex Fergusson stand and sitting on the seats viewing the stadium for the first time. You could see Ben was in awe of the size of the place. We had a couple of good tour guides and visited the dressing rooms, 3 areas of the seating, the tunnel, the press conference room, where the directors hang out and sit in the dug out seats. Really good. We loved the 90 minute tour. We visited the megastore and bought some sweatbands and captains armband before re-visiting the museum once again briefly.

We all met up again mid-afternoon and set off for Manchester City Centre and the Arndale Centre. Daddy's next treat was a Topps Match Attax swapping event! Ben indulged in a Match Attax game against some other poor kid, who got pummelled 14-1 by Ben. He got a packet of cards for his troubles. We skirted the town hall before returning back to the car.

Back to Didsbury, via the Ethiad Stadium, where City play. We ate at a Weatherspoons, hotel, then bed.

Theatre Of Dreams

United Trinity plus Ben

Museum start

Reds Café with Charlton and Cantona

In the Alex Fergusson stand

Father and Son supporters

Reds make a key signing

Stepping into Rooney's boots or shirt

Badged up

Post Match Interview

New Man Utd Manager

Trophy Room

Premier League Trophy

Match Attax Game in Arndale Centre

Manchester Town Hall

title.value: Manchester Break - Old Trafford, Shopping, Topps Cards, Ethiad

info.content:
What would day 2 have in store. First up, the all important breakfast. Eat all you can buffet, including cooked breakfast, which us children took, and then did not eat! Dustbin Daddy obliged.

Then off to the Trafford Centre again, this time to the Lego Discovery Centre. Ben was very excited, showing us around the shop. It's so expensive considering they are plastic bricks. We entered via the lift taken on a introductory tour, them let loose on the Lego scenes and activities that you could participate in. We also had a go at a shooting game, which Katie won!

Full on fight in the Lego shop

Catching the colourful Lego lift

The main events were a 4D cinema with Lego characters, a build your own car and race exercise, which again Katie won, a karaoke setup wierdly enough and a lego construction lesson. Overall I think we spent 4 or 5 hours in there. A thumbs up from us.

Lego Blackpool at night

Lego car making

Preparing for a family karaoke sing song

Dodging the lazer beams game

We returned back to the hotel, Daddy went for a run along the River Mersey, then we all walked up to the Greenfinch pub for dinner. Spirits were high and the food and drink cheap!

Mummy and Daddy in the Greenfinch

Dadda and KT

The final instalment of Daddy's 40th birthday celebrations a semi surprise trip to Manchester. Surprise in that all Daddy knows is that we have 4 days in and around Manchester, visiting Old Trafford. The rest is a mystery, including the first activity.

We pulled up in the Trafford Centre, where there are a bazillion shops and activities. However, one building sores above most. The Chill Factor ski slope! We had an hour to play in the snow and go do-nutting, sledging and luging. It was pretty cold in there. The luge did not satisfy Daddy's bucket list item, but the sledging was quick and do-nutting was fun. We had an hour free reign on what we wanted.

It's snow time

Mummy looking at home with a donut!

Luging

Trying to keep sledge under control

We returned to our hotel between Didsbury and Nothenden. The Britannia Country House. It was quite hard to find a room that would fit the 5 of us. We had a Jacuzzi bath which pleased us children!

Daddy was woken by Katie luckily as he had to get out early for a 8:30 start at Walton on Thames bridge. He was running with his work colleague, Anthony. They both had been training quite a bit for this event. Daddy's target was to beat Basingstoke's time two weeks ago. In all honestly he should do. The course is flat, the conditions cool and perfect, he'd had another 2 weeks of training and had Anthony there to push him along.

The run was good. Three ladies fell in front of the pair through out the course which was a little strange. Otherwise the pace was good and very consistent. The target was to be in and around the 1:50 pacer. He was overtaken at about mile 6. From then on it was a slight quickening of the pace to the finish. Perfect. They came in together at 1:47.46. A fantastic time.

Racing to the finish

The stats

Medalists

title.value: River Thames Half Marathon - New PB - 1:47.46

info.content:
Daddy parkrunned in the morning. In the afternoon Jessica went to a birthday party at Tomlinscote. Meanwhile the rest of us went to the Fars for a cup of tea and do a few jobbies.

We picked up Jessica and all cycled into Camberley, on Daddy's not so short cut! We voted to go the 'car' way on the way home. In Camberley Ben bought a metal tin with Match Attax cards in, Katie, Jessica, Daddy and Mummy all got some clothes. The way home saw a race between Daddy and Jessica versus the rest. Good fun! We all watched the end of 'Hunted' and saw the first two episodes of the Apprentice. Nice to have all 5 of us doing stuff together.

title.value: Bike Ride, Jessica to party, Fars

info.content: Daddy cooked up a Sunday roast, partially done on the BBQ, with a cherry pie that could have been better!... The victims? Auntie Susan and Graham. It was nice to catch up with them and give Graham his birthday present.

Katie reluctantly went along with the guides to the Big Gig. An event only for Guides at Wembley Arena where a number of acts were performing throughout the afternoon. Acts included: Ella Henderson, Aston Merrygold, Nathan Sykes and the Foxes.

She did have a bit of a panic attack just due to the large number of people in one place, but she did enjoy it more than she thought she would. However, not enough to go next year! Strange because we thought it would be right up her street.

Daddy took over Uncle Michael's place at the Basingstoke Half Marathon. For a change Daddy was going to run alone. No prep in terms of looking up the route and how hilly it was, however, plenty of prep in training runs.

The weather was perfect. No wind, nice temperature, no rain and a 11am start. Within the first mile Daddy's feet were in pain. Thin soles and plenty of walking yesterday at Chessington. Although this occupied Daddy's mind for much of the start, the scenery in the Basingstoke sticks soon distracted him away from the pain. Learning from the 100 mile bike ride two weeks back, Daddy just ran at a steady, non-pushing pace. The whole course was hills. Long up hills mixed in with steep downs. Daddy felt good and pushed on.

A surprise meeting of the Fars at 9 miles.... then 12 miles. The legs started to really struggle. The last mile was hard. Both the Fars and us lot were there on the finishing stretch to cheer Daddy home. He crossed the line in 1:52.55, a new PB. Daddy fell to the floor exhausted, his feet really hurting him.

Daddy ended up not being able to put much weight on both his feet. He struggled with the Fars help to the St. John's Ambulance.... but they couldn't do anything for him. It was a muscle strain or cramp or something. He struggled to walk for the next two hours. Anyway pleased with a PB on a hilly course.

Running down the home straight

The vital stats

After some in the family had a disappointing trip to Chessington, due to closed rides, we got free tickets to revisit. This time we took Daddy and Pop Pop along with us.

We managed to get around all the rides we wanted to get on. Jessica's favourite ride was the first, Dragons Fury. At one point she unusually got scared as for a split second she went very quiet. However, she recovered and loved it. For the rest of us the Vampire was the best ride, despite the 80 minute queue!

Banger Racing... Dodgem style

Ben on the Log Flume with Pop Pop

Jessica walking a tight rope as there aren't enough scary activities for her!

Katie and Ben at the Magic Tree

After church we went down to Hayling Island on this gloriously sunny day. Daddy brought down the kayak and took all the kiddies for excursions out to sea. We had a big game of volleyball come netball.... and ma ma treated us to a few fairground rides.

Kayaking out to sea

Some form of volleyball game

Ben finally got to have his birthday party treat, both a paintball party and sleepover. Effingham was the destination, 7 friends; Oliver, Joey Elder, Joey Harris, Yuvraj, Michael S, Freddy and Kieron. They played three games; first is the castle, then speedball and finally xxxxx. They had a great time.

Meanwhile, the girls played over at Natasha's house and Daddy sneaked in the Guildford parkrun (22:36) before coming over to paintball.

We all gathered back at the house for pizza, and later a game of football at the rec. Dad was ref and we had a five a-side match, 12 minutes each way. The final score was 2-1. Ben unfortunately on the losing side.

Half the party left, the other half stayed for a sleepover which involved playing the new Fifa 16, Nerf gun fights, football and Match Of The Day. Final bed-time was 4am!

Paintball army

Cadet Gay

Frugle Benjie

Platoon with their big gun

title.value: Ben Belated Birthday Party - Paintball and Sleepover

info.content:
Ben was voted in as school Captain for Endurance house. This joins up with his other responsibility of being on the Sports Council. Proud of you big boys.

Announcement in school publication of Ben's captaincy

We hadn't seen the Dixons for over a year, so was nice to catch up with them. After church we all travelled up to Apsley. David and Lisa were the same as ever. Reuben has much bigger feet than Ben despite bring 3 years younger. Yasmin is lovely. Very well spoken.

We had lunch and went to the local swing park for a game of football, cricket and crocodiles!

Footer

The girls having a natter

Daddy and Ben stayed overnight with the Elders as Daddy had an early start for the New Forest Sportive 100. A 100 mile+ bike ride with Michael and Robin.

Despite not training for it, and having low confidence of completing the 104 miles, the riders were all surprised to roll in at 8:30 hours. It was a lovely ride in the New Forest. At one point they had 8 wild horses galloping parallel with them. A beautiful sight.

The route... 104 miles in 8:30 hours

The boys picked up their medals, averaging 12mph.

Daddy, Robin and Michael at the finish

Meanwhile, Katie went to the Thames at Shepperton to sail her cardboard kayak with the Guides.

Daddy ran his quickest parkrun for about 6 months, just dipping under 23 minutes which he was pleased about.

This year Jessica's party was hosted here at home. 10 friends came to join in the fun and games that Mummy had organised.

Dancing party go-ers

Party food time!

The two hours flew by. All the girls behaved really well.

Present opening

In the evening Daddy went out with Steve to watch Man Utd beat Liverpool, then onto the White House, Guildford for Darren's MacCaskill's 40th Birthday Do.

In the morning we opened presents. Jessica was letting everyone know on the days leading to today about her birthday. She checked each card carefully for any cash! Shocking. She was given some Lego Friends, money, a dress, some books and make-up stuff.

Jessica opening cards

In the evening we met up with Daddy at Frankie And Benny's for a nice meal.

Daddy and us

Cocktail Girls

Katie

Mumma

As the boys were in Munich the rest of us went to Auntie Ellie's to spend the night. Mummy went to Fiona's house to celebrate her 40th birthday.

Mummy at Fiona's Party

There was dissent in the ranks. Bazza and Kingster were not that enthusiastic to hire bikes and go for a jolly jaunt around Munich. However, they accompanied the other three down to the railway station where it so happened hundreds of refugees from Syria and the likes were disembarking trains. After about 45 minutes of doing more laps, the boys eventually found the bike hire place. Made difficult as there were TV crews, police cordons and barriers blocking the path to the bike hire place. All we wanted was three bikes! Anyway, Slop got stuck in the middle of the refugees passage, so began walking where the refugees walked. A policeman called him back, but he continued down into the hallway of the station hoping to find an exit. Eventually, Slop was turned back and marched back to where he had came and let through the barriers and freedom!

Munich Cycle Route

So we split. The biking boys headed north, past the Stadion, relaying Friday nights activities to a forgetful Dawg. A 20 minute cycle up to the Olympic park. The normal Olympic games ensued. i.e. trying to knock each other off the bikes.

Olympic Park

They toured about the park, saw the stadium and the swimming pool and ventured up the Olympic Tower and saw Munich from a great height!

Olympic Tower

Meanwhile the other two were touring the train system of Munich.

BMW world next, a fleeting visit, then a cycle through the Englischer Garten where there was some surfing and a quick stop for a sausage and a litre of beer. More hi-jinx on the rush back to the station to meet the others..... who were not impressed by their late arrival! E'ster forgot to ring through!

Englischer Garten

We were all split on the plane. Slop sat next to the child from hell who screamed and misbehaved all the way back! Pappa G and the Railair link provided the transport back home.

A great trip boys. Cheers.

A good nights sleep and we needed to get going as we had booked a tour around the Allianz Arena, where Bayern Munich play. This involved a Metro trip northwards with a fragile Dawg.

Dawg a little hungover

The Allianz Arena stood in the middle of waste land it seemed. It looked impressive. It was a bit of a walk from the station. The guide for our tour was not the most engaging. Having said that, the trip around was good for 10 euros. We went high in the stands, in the dressing rooms, down the tunnel, the press conference area, and pitch side. It took an hour and a bit to complete.

Allianz Arena

We returned back into Munich and headed for the centre, Marienplatz. We did some laps. Baz spent £20 on about 10 prawns. Next stop Hofbräuhaus, a famous drinking establishment once frequented by Hitler! There was a Oompa Loompa band and some more stiens.... or in E'ster case, small Radlers (shandy). Apparently saving himself for a big session in the evening! Did that ever happen?

Hofbrauhaus

Baz got chatting to a hen party.... and managed to come out with his nails varnished in bright red! Dawg brought to the table another drinking game, something a little simpler than counting hopefully so Bazza wouldn't be drinking the kitty dry. Played with cards, each number on the card had a separate rule. The best was the Jack where if the 'Jack' person asked a question you were not allowed to answer. This seemed to trip Dawg up the most surprisingly.

After a couple of litres of ale, E'ster and Dawg went back to the hostel for a kip and to put makeup on, whilst the hardcore drinkers moved on to the Hard Rock café.... and it was Queen day. Music to Slop's ears. Another beer and a short later and the 3 boys were sold by this a girl a rickshaw ride to Ned Kelly's. What a ride. The poor girl didn't know what had hit her. They shouted out 'Move it or lose it sister' to the unsuspecting public. Plenty of noise. Then Jonah forgot his jumper, so she had to turn back. By the end of the 15 minute journey the girl was out of breathe. She was rewarded well though. The infamous 5 were back together. Ned Kelly's and England v San Marino and another beer. A largely uneventful game, other than the 6 goals that is! Mikey still warming up his drinking arm.

We returned to the Wombats. Slop was in the communal area testing the hammocks out. The opportunity was too great for Bazza who tipped Slop on to his head and dragged him to the side of the hall. Others in the room were horrified. Slop and Bazza were sniggering like little school children. We claimed our free drinks at the Wombats Bar. Bazza tried out a bit of pole dancing. It didn't last long when he struggled to lift himself up.

Next some laps. Laps around some of the seedier areas of Munich.... then into a very chintzy, red bar. E'ster was now on a mission. :) Baz was mentioning quite loudly how he thought it was a gay bar. We moved on again and the evening sort of petered out. Baz at the kebab place.

  • After sending in his order:
  • Server: Do you want beef or chicken?
  • Bazza: I WANT A KEBABBBB that's shouty font!

Well the boys had peeked it seemed. In bed just before midnight, not before Bazza stole, E'sters sweeties intended for Toby! Nasty man.

Some would say an excuse for a boys tour away. Others have put it down as 40th birthday celebration! Daddy, Michael, Steven, Nick and Barrie or Slop, E'ster, Dawg, Kingster and Bazza all decided to go to Munich for a long weekend. It started with taxis from Messrs Papa Gay and Papa Barnett. A 6:30am departure for a meet at Heathrow Terminal 2. E'ster having not travelled much did not managed to comprehend that a nearly empty shower gel in a 250ml bottle will not get through security. Despite being told, he tried to sneak it through. He got stopped and had to empty his bag. The hi-jonx had already started. Baz left his e-cigarette pipe thing behind. Fortunately E'ster picked it up. Of course not letting on. We saw Baz running around looking for it.... yes Bazza actually running. He was desperate. Having left his bag unattended, a rummage through the bag saw an interesting pair of shoes which Slop took for later! the first beers were served up at 8am.

8am beer at Terminal 2

Then came the flight.... It was only 2 hours. Man alive it was incident filled. We all sat together. First off, Baz was showing some videos on his phone which the woman in front of us appreciated! Then a trolley came around with drinks and food..... Beer number 2. More than one drink could be ordered.... so Slop had a coffee and orange juice. It didn't go too well. The coffee was spilt everywhere! Then Dawg proceeded to spill his beer and Bazza his orange juice on the person sat next to him!

Plane mess

Bazza went to the toilet and got stuck between the trolleys going up the gangway. Whilst he was waiting he cheekily asked for another beer!... Unsurprisingly his wish was granted, so was drinking beer at 9am on the gangway. This opened the floodgates for the rest of the plane to order subsequent beers!

On ordering the third beer, E'ster decided to get up and go to the toilet. Shuffling along Slop left his foot out on the gangway which tripped up the air stewardess who was serving the beer. Then E'ster wouldn't take the beer as he got up waiting to get out to the toilet. The male steward then came over, an excused Slop of purposely tripping up the air stewardess. As E'ster didn't take the beer there was a stand off between giving and receiving the beer. It got a bit tense for a bit. We were not ideal passengers I suspect. This coupled with Baz getting his suitcase down for the umpteenth time looking for his e-cigarettes we were right pains in the necks!

We arrived.... first a chance to change footwear... By the way Bazza never got to wear his winkle pickers over the whole trip!

Nice shoes

Baz struck up a conversation with passport control.....

  • Passport Controller: ... in Bazzas ears he thought he said 'Are you from Bracknell?'. Not that Bracknell is on his passport or anything.
  • Bazza: No, I'm from Fleet. I work in Bracknell. Do you know Bracknell?
  • Passport Controller: No ..... looking a bit bemused!

We metro'ed it down to the Wombat Hostel, the seventh best chain in the world, don't you know! The room was clean and reasonably spacious. Bazza now lost some additional filters or something. He was all over the place. After the hardship of making our own beds we wandered out to E'sters first stop, Botanischen Garten, a beer garden and our first stiens. Baz could not handle it anymore. He needed nicotine. Just before plundering 10 euros into the cigarette machine, his true whereabouts of his e-cig thing were revealed!

Botanischen Garten

We caught a tram to Hirschgarten for another beer and some sausage! The first of the drinking games commenced. 21s. This involved counting up.... a concept that Bazza found hard to grasp. Either that or he liked drinking! Next Augistinerkeller...

Slop and Bazza laughing at Dawg and Kingster

Dawg and Kingster laughing at Slop and Bazza

Next stop.... Germany v Poland in a Euro qualifier. We needed a good football bar. Thankfully the research before we left led us going to the Stadion. A busy pub with a reserved bench in front of the TV just for us. Like clockwork. We got chatting to some locals. Some of us were flagging under the weighty stiens. Still it didn't stop some.... in fact some accelerated the consumption rate.

Stadion

.... Some stood up and gave a speech in their semi german accent! "Silence!!!". The game was quality, the beer was flowing. A good night.

The pace was too much for E'ster. He sat on a step outside for the whole of the second half. Slop needed food to soak up the alcohol. Dawg went loopy..... as if he had lost his bone! It made for an interesting trek home. There were tantrums, sprinting, and a lot of stopping. Eventually we made the last tram back to the hostel at 2am. The dawg was in a bad way.

So, another new school year. Jessica was looking forward to starting Frimley C of E, joining Ben. Katie still at Tomlinescote

The sensible one

I let them have this one

Mummy and Daddy were married 15 years ago. To celebrate Paula came around to babysit and the love birds went out to the Blue Smoke House in Bracknell. A very tasty meal.

Going out

Our first walk in ages.... well I say walk, us kiddies had bikes. Even the bikes didn't take the edge of it being a walk! Still Mummy and Daddy forced us to go. The weather wasn't great, but we did visit Basing House and walk around Basingstoke Common. All the girls were getting scared of the cows which we had to walk around a number of times. We split in the end, kiddies over the fence, Mummy running away in a field when a cow moo'ed, Daddy left behind shaking his head walking normally on the prescribed routed!

Old Basing House

Daddy took a dead bush out of the garden and took it down the dump.

Bush on the roof

It worked.... just. He did have to stop after going around the mini roundabout in Frimley as the bush rolled off to one side and was hanging down. Daddy also passed a police car going in the opposite direction which was tense... Deposited in the dump successfully.

We had 25 comes to ours for Frimcot. Mainly the Barnett side of the family came over for the BBQ cross Race afternoon. Farmor walked away with the 80 pounds prize!

Those inside watching the horse racing

Those outside enjoying the wine and weather

In the morning Daddy went to parkrun at Frimley Lodge and ran slowly!

Daddy park running

In the evening we went to Farfar's 69th birthday meal which we had in the backgarden. Farmor cooked a lovely meal and Farfar had prepared a treasure hunt.

Birthday boy still had granddad duties

Do you like the flag table cloths?

Katie and Jessica were inspired by this week's Great British Bake Off. It was bread week. They spent 2 or 3 days making lots and lots of bread.... more than we could eat. They got quite inventive. Did it all themselves. Well done girls.

Breadmakers

We met up with Fi, Tom and Natasha at Danson Park and played in the sprayground.

Tom and Ben being sprayed

Ben's airboot, which he has been wearing on and off for about 4 weeks can now be returned. He can walk now unaided. The wound and muscle behind his lower leg has now healed nicely. It's just the muscle that still needs building up. He can walk with less of a tip-toe action than before the operation. The physio has still warned us that if the muscle does not recover then another, different operation will be needed. Ben is well chuffed.

After church we headed into the New Forest and to Lepe Country Park to meet with Daddy's friend Michael. Michael had set up an interview for Thursday to come and join him.

Lepe Country Park

Lepe Beach

Yesterday we left Daddy and headed west into Wales. The Sat Nav was set to avoid Tolls, so we went a scenic route and didn't arrive until 1pm. Our small tent was setup and we headed off to the beach.

Daddy came down on Wednesday and met us at Llanmadoc Beach where we were building a dam. Mummy seemed thrilled for Daddy's arrival she almost said hello to him!

In the afternoon the boys played Pitch And Putt at the Mumbles, whilst the girls played Crazy Golf. Daddy won!

In the evening we headed down to Rotherslade Beach, climbed rocks had a BBQ and went in the sea.

Rotherslade Rock

BBQing at Rotherslade

In the evening we waited up at the camp site to see the meteor shower. Lots of shooting stars. First time we had even seen that.

On the Thursday we went to Joe's Ice Cream parlour in the morning, then went to the Black Pill paddling pool. It was a little chilly but didn't phase the children. Also there was a playground which we had a good go at.

Jessica At Black Pill Paddling Pool

Katie and Auntie Ellie

Later Daddy and Michael went off for a bike ride from the campsite to Rhossili and back again. A 20 miler in the pouring rain. Meanwhile the rest of us went on the pier at the end of the Mumbles.

On the Friday the weather wasn't very inviting. We decided to head into Swansea and go to the Leisure Centre. According to Trip Advisor one of the top 20 water parks in Europe! I think not. The children had a good time.

In the afternoon, Ben, Daddy and Michael all went out on the kayak from Oxwich Bay. It was lovely and relaxing. Michael brought his fishing rod and a line with four hooks..... and he caught 4 mackerel in one go. Fantastic. They were out there for a good hour and a half. Very relaxing. Later the children and boys went to the pub to see Man Utd play Aston Villa.

Saturday and pack up morning. Daddy was ill and threw up in the bushes behind the tents. On the way home he needed to sleep at the services!

Happy Campers

Daddy met with James and Emma for Frimley Lodge Live. As we had taken the camping chairs Daddy wheelbarrowed 3 patio chairs down to Frimley Lodge Park!

Daddy took a bite of a sandwhich, not noticing a wasp. Needless to say the wasp stung daddy in the mouth! Ouch.

A Bon Jovi tribute band were first up.... a bit ropey. Next, Bob Marley, then a passable U2 band. Then came the headline act, Queen. Emma laughed at Daddy's and James' dancing, air guitaring and all round wally-ness. It was fun!

A day after our holiday, but still we got up early for Ben's present opening, of course in Mummy and Daddy's room. Presents were a bit limited this morning, having not seen anyone in the past week. However, Ben got some books and Lego and had a shopping trip later to get some clothes.

Reading Katie's Card

The shopping trip to Camberley was accompanied by the Fars. They treated us to some bits and pieces like cakes and clothes! Ben ordered his Man Utd, Ben 10 kit.... The fars were impressed by Ben's focus when it came to shopping for clothes. Pretty much up till now, his clothes have been 99% hand me downs, so a chance to express himself and carve his own little identity and style out.

So, we should explain, Ben was going to have a paintball party with his friends, but due to his leg this has been postponed until late September now. We also tried to book tickets to see the Harry Potter studios. However, they have been fully booked!

In the evening we went out to McDonalds in Camberley and met up with Dad for dinner. Although a little low key for a boys 10th birthday, Ben seemed to have had a good time.

We tried to eek as much out of the villa on the final day. The cleaner and gardener were flitting around preparing for the next visitors. We were packing up and playing in the pool 30 minutes later than we should have. We were sorry to leave Casa Tilias.

In a bid to kill time we decided to take a scenic route and go via Vilamoura Marina. This was a very plush area with sports cars parked in the nearby hotel. We ate lunch at the marina and carried on to Faro. Mummy was getting nervous of time. Daddy was the opposite. We handed back the car, then had 3 hours to wait at the airport!

We touched down in England. The weather not too bad. Caught a bus back to our housing estate in Horley, got fish and chips and made our way home. We entered the house at about 9:30pm. What a lovely holiday.

The view from the roof terrace

final dip

Vilamoura marina for lunch

Arguably the highlight of the holiday. Jessica loves her Dolphins and Mummy decided to treat us all (but didn't fancy it herself) for a special swim session with them. We arrived early, taken to a special area, given a briefing and then to spend half an hour with the dolphins. We were able to dance with them, stroke them, kiss them and at the end they pushed us along the water. What a fantastic experience. Aquamarine did a fantastic job. We got some nice complimentary bits and pieces as well. We all love a bit of free stuff.

Katie and Hugo dancing

Ben tickling his chin

Dolphin Group Shot

Katie giving him a big smacker

Jessica and Dolphin love

11am and now the rest of Aquamarine to explore. It's kind of half water park, with a number of slides, big swimming pool and beach area, and half sea life centre, with a number of animal demonstrations. One of which was of course the Dolphin Show. We sat in the stands beforehand and the music was blaring out. Ben was dancing or wiggling to the music. The camera caught him and there he was in front of hundreds of people on the big screen dancing to everyone. Not being shy, he loved it and carried on. Definitely not come from Mummy or Daddy's stock!

Sliding down

Ben dancing on the big screen

We went in the outdoor wave machine pool, saw the pirate show and went in the 4D cinema before the park shut. There was more to do.

In the evening we returned to the baker shop from the other day. It was not just a baker shop, it also doubled up as a restaurant. The service was first class and food delightful. Being the last night, we all reflected and remarked what a good time we had.

Enjoying a meal at our favourite restaurant

title.value: Portugal Holiday - Day 7 - Aquamarine, swimming with Dolphins

info.content:
We headed off to Portimão which was about 40 miles west just to see another area of Portugal. Rachel and Jon had recommended Praia da Rocha. We parked up and walked. It was hot and sunny and the sandy beach was huge. There was a big handball tournament going on at the beach. The children were hot and grumpy. Just around the corner Daddy spotted an inflatable assault course moored 30 meters out to sea. So we all had a go on that. Despite the weather, the sea water seemed freezing. The five of us paddled out to the assault course and played on it for an hour and a half. There were slides, a platform to jump off (which Daddy slipped off) and various obstacles to negotiate. It was different and fun.

The assault course

Later in the afternoon we returned to Albuferia Marina and went on a boat trip along the coast, westwards, back towards where we were staying in fact.

It was nice to cruise along the coast, soaking up the weather and the scenary. About 45 minutes in we stopped for a bit. This is where the dinghy came out and trips around the caves were made. Only 10 at a time, so whilst waiting they got the slide out, and you could slide off the boat and into the Med! Daddy was first to try on the boat. We all had a go. Mummy loved it. The trip around the caves were good. A busy stopping point for all the boat excursions.

Daddy and Katie on the boat

Katie sliding off the boat

Dinghy into the caves

In the evening again we trotted into Albuferia walked around the streets. Ben was enthralled by the chap who was doing keepy-upy's with the football. I think he could have watched him all night. We were amazed at how big and busy Albuferia was. It had a buzzing, lively atmosphere. Don't think we ever got our bearings at this place. Still it was nice to get lost.

Ben fascinated by Mr. Keepy Uppy

title.value: Portugal Holiday - Day 6 - Portimão, Boat Trip

info.content:
We stocked up on lunch at this lovely bakery en-route this morning. The biggest croissants you would ever find.

Another monster water park. Today Slide and Splash. A bit further away, but today we were fully prepared to get there before it starts and leave as late as possible. Similar price to Aqualand at about the £60 mark.

It looked very impressive when we entered the park, and Ben laying down the mission to go on every slide at least once. It was early, the queues relatively quiet, so let's make hay. There were more slides than Aqualand, however, there were a lot of similar styled flumes at many more with unnecessary height restrictions. Hard to say which was better. That's my Trip Advisor bit over with.

Slide and Splash Family shot

Katie and Ben enjoying the scare Black Hole

Which slide has she come from?

title.value: Portugal Holiday - Day 5 - Slide And Splash

info.content:
Another morning of pool side antics.

That animal will eat you up!

The afternoon was spent looking for a Go Ape type of place on the other side of Albuferia. It was slightly different, not quite as high as Alice Holt or Bracknell, but had zip wires from tree to tree, different challenges. Overall a bit more exciting Daddy would say.

Through the mighty jungle

The cargo net

Jessica not going out with shoes on ruled her out, Ben with his leg ruled him out, so it was just Daddy and Katie to tackle the entire course.

In the evening we hit a local bar, Snoopy's, which had a swimming pool. When I say local, everyone was English. Daddy could connect to WiFi to see how much money we had left on the travel card and watch some Rugby League, Mummy enjoyed a cocktail as did us kiddies. There was another swimming pool to test out this evening!

Snoopy's pool slide - Katie belly first

title.value: Portugal Holiday - Day 4 - Go Ape, Snoopy's Bar

info.content:
This is where the serious fun was going to be started. A water park in the sun. We never had been. A similar excitement to when we visit a theme park, this time with a twist. Aqualand is one of the main water parks in the Algarve, boasting massive flumes, a lazy river, kids play areas and a huge outdoor swimming pool. Entry was about £60 for the five of us, which was good value.

Aqualand

The mission was to go on everything possible. There must have been 15 slides+ in total. So there was a lot of work to do!

Mummy and Jessica enjoying a swim

The biggest slide of all was a terrifying drop slide, which we all agreed to go on. Mummy bottle straight away. Ben and Jessica were too small, so it was left to Katie and a nervous Daddy. Katie walking half way up already convinced herself it was too scarey, so this left just Daddy! Daddy sat on the toboggan, the electronic shelf then tip him forward and the barrier was removed and very quickly daddy was hurtling down the slide and skimming across the water coming to an undignified splash at the end.

We had a great time and we were sad to run out of time and returned home when the park closed at about 6pm. BBQ for dinner!

We decided to have an easy-ish day today. Settle into life. A trip to Lidl was first stop to see what the supermarkets had to offer. Lots of fish and a nice bakery section which satisfied the children.

We played in the pool for most of the morning. This entertained us for hours and hours over the holiday. So many games, challenges and relaxes to do. Worth bringing a load of pool toys. The most popular were Daddy's diving mask.

One of the top beaches in the Algarve was Gale beach, according to Trip Advisor. It was just 2 miles away, so we drove down (remember Ben has a bad leg). It was pretty hot and busy. I think we all were happy to experience the sandy beach, but quite happy to have the privacy and relaxation of the pool back at the villa.

Jessica with a drink problem?

The sea had some good waves which knocked us about a bit. It also had some rocks which we could climb.

Jessica at Gale beach

Later in the afternoon we played in the pool some more, before we returned back into Albuferia for another mooch about and look what we could spend / waste our holiday money on!

Katie illuminated by the beach tunnel, Albuferia.

Family at the square in Albuferia

title.value: Portugal Holiday - Day 2 - Swimming, Gale Beach, Albuferia

info.content:
We've splashed out this year, mainly as we'd saved to go to Florida, but Katie didn't fancy a long flight, so instead we decided on a sunny Algarve.

Return Mr Daddy Tightwad. Normal people would catch a train to Gatwick or park in one of the supplied car parks. Not Daddy. He drives us to a housing estate in Horley where he parks the car, then we catch a local bus into the airport. He reckons this save £70.

Waiting at a bus stop in Horley

Anyway, this ran surprisingly smoothly. We check in, passport, scanning...... although Katie inadvertently tried to smuggle some perfume across, which once checked, she was allowed.... and take off. The Norwegian Airways flight did not have us all sitting together. Katie and Mummy were very nervous flyers but seemed to get through it ok.

Waiting at a plane stop in Gatwick

Flying over Spain and Portugal the terrain was very brown and rocky it appeared. Not much greenery or fields. This was something we were not expecting. We landed at Faro airport, then part 2 of Daddy's cheapness - car rental.

All the big car rental firms were at one end of the airport with dedicated desks in the airport and big signs. So we pushed the heavy trolley up to that end thinking all car rentals must be together. 'Auto Rent' however were not. You guessed it. They were up the other end of the airport building, out the door and in car park 4. Pushing a heavy trolley in jeans in that heat, negotiating all the humps. bumps, curbs and oblivious people was not a fun experience. There was a portacabin finally we'd got there. Nope. So the second tier, local established firms operated out of here. Not 'Auto Rent'. This is where we picked the mini-bus up where the grumpy driver drove us 2 miles down to the road to the car yard. Unperturbed, the kids were excited about getting a new car. Apparently they wanted the white car... the kind man duly obliged and we were off...... off in the wrong direction initially, but at least we were moving. Set on the correct road out of Faro, we soon hit a 'road closed' sign. We were forced off onto the local roads. No diversion signs, no map, a choice of two directions running at right angles to the original road. It was literally a coin toss on which way to go. We turned left, eventually saw a town sign, got the mobile phone out and looked at Google Maps to see which way to go. Eventually we re-joined the main road again and headed towards Albuferia.

After over an hours driving we ended up in the jungle of villas to the east of Albuferia. We had a map, no road name. Portugal don't believe in road name signs or town signs. It is always difficult to know where you are. Every road looks to the same, there are no distinguishing features. We were going around in circles in the right area. Anyway after another U-turn in a side road, daddy unconsciously drove in 'English' mode. Was on the left hand side of the road. Turned out of the junction left, continued slow-ish for about 20 yards. All of a sudden, two oncoming cars appear. Ahhh. We're on the wrong side of the road. Without checking, daddy steered right (onto the correct side of the road), however, some woman was trying to overtake, so as we pulled across we cut her up. She slammed her brakes on, tyres squealing on her car, the smell of rubber masked the other smells which may have slipped out! The woman raised her arms in exasperation. Daddy, sheepishly pulled away. I would question why the woman was trying to overtake when she saw a daft foreigner on the wrong side of the road!

Driving wrong side of road

After Google Maps told us where we were, we quickly found the villa. First we saw a For Sale sign and then what appeared to be locked gates to the property. Phone calls back to England proved unfruitful. Our Portuguese contact did not answer the phone. Oh dear. We've been sold a pup.

Whilst we were climbing / playing / mucking around with the gate, Katie managed to 'unlock' it. The property from the outside was gorgeous. Next, the front door - locked. The key inside a mini-safe which we didn't have the paperwork for! Suspected that Daddy threw it away. A call back to Gemma and she gave a few numbers to try. BINGO. Key in the door.... still no entry! After a bit of stress and shaking the door (needed a technique) enter Ali Baba. What an ordeal to get to this point.

Casa Tilias Villa

Us youngsters jumped in the pool straight away. How cool and refreshing. Daddy was in charge of inflating bits of PVC. Mummy unpacked. We enjoyed exploring the large villa which looking later was up for sale at £450k. Swap houses?

In the evening we decided to venture into Albuferia, about a 10 minute drive away. We really felt on holiday now. Shorts, T-shirt, flip flops and free town parking! Albuferia was a lovely large town. Yes it was 100% aimed at tourists with gift shops and bars, but as long as you had that in mind, it was a lovely setting. No drunks, or beggers or hard salesman. It was reasonably cheap as well, probably due to the strong pound. We decided to stop and eat at a traditional Portuguese eating parlour. Well if Daddy had his way, however it was a Hamburger Restaurant we stopped at. At this point was really suffering in hindsight with exhaustion. It had been a long day, with the heat and the crutches it all took it's toll. Drakness descended and we headed back to the villa for a much needed good night's sleep.

Exploring the streets of Albuferia
Dani, one of Katie's friends who came to her party, invited Katie to her sisters 18th birthday. They went to a Lama farm and walked Lamas!

Daddy ran his fastest parkrun in a while.

After lunch Ben had Michael S's birthday do which was held at the Quays. It was a kayaking party, which we were a bit nervous about at first because of his leg. However, it was the first time he could physically get involved and play with his friends for a long while. There were many smiles on Ben's face. He loved it.

They played a number of games, including 'it' and had water fights.

Speed merchant

Ben and Oli

Ben enjoying Kayaking

Ben circling his prey

6am and it was time to wake up. We've never seen someone so excited about their birthday. Days, weeks of anticipation..... not for presents as such, but for Go Ape and the impending party / sleepover.

First up, breakfast in mummy and daddy's bed with present opening. Katie already got a camera, but she opened presents with make up, a Ted Baker handbag and clothes.

The weather was not great for GoApe. It was raining..... persistently! We met with the Elders, Pop Pop and Farmor at Alice Holt. Jessica, Lily, Farmor and Pop Pop went up on the junior version of the tree apparatus, whilst Mummy, Katie and Joey went on the adult version, which had 5 stages.

Jess and Lily on the trial GoApe course

Jessica was a little nervous, listened carefully to the instructor beforehand, but she did ever so well. Katie was not scared at all. It was the highlight of her birthday. She loved it.

Katie zipping down

It was so wet and horrible outside that many returned home before the 'adult' clamberers returned to tera firma. Ellie took Ben and Jessica, whilst Lily returned home with Katie. Katie's guests arrived at 4pm.... the weather still no better thus spoiling the hoards going in the back garden. No matter, we had made up plenty of games to keep everyone entertained. The Flip Flops versus the Lilo combat began first with a game of Titles (Timed Pictionary), then Spoons, a music quiz and loads of other games. The girls decided to ignore the rain and went out and played in the paddling pool. Mummy had made another game up for the paddling pool as well!

Present opening

The evening rolled on with dinner, a sing song of happy birthday with cake. The film 'Home' proved only to last about 45 minutes in the family room, before everyone descended in to the front room to play on phones / laptops / watch music tv. As the parents went to bed, a game of snog, marry, avoid ensued.

Mad girls in the rain and paddling pool

Having not met many of Katie's friends before, Mummy and Daddy were delighted to see what a nice set of mates Katie has got. The only 'old' friend was Leah R. Katie said she fell asleep at 4am!

Daddy had an interesting day up in London first. He was invited to go along with Ruth and Mia to a customer, JLT in Aldgate. Plush, glass offices with glass lifts on the inside. Very swanky.

JLT Offices

After been taken out for a nice Italian meal, Daddy headed off to Paddington to catch a train to Maidenhead. Picked up by the Fars and taken to the River Thames for a nice Ice Cream. Then they went the scenic route to Wycombe Air Park where they met us!

This is the gliding club that Uncle Ron used to fly at. A couple of his friends were around Michael and Bob, who spoke warmly of Ron. Bob was taking Daddy up in a two seater glider... and letting him have a go on the controls. Both Mummy and Katie were scared stiff, Ben and Katie were a little braver. We all walked onto the grass airfield and saw Daddy being briefed and dressed for the occasion. He was sat the front with all the dials and joystick in front of him.

Take off time. The aeroplane pulled away dragging Daddy and Bob along. Katie was in tears, Mummy laughing in nervousness, Ben and Jess loving the adventure. They were towed to a height of 3000 metres at 70mph. All of a sudden the rope was disengaged which was a little disconcerting at first, but once everything had stabilized it was a relaxing experience.

The speed dropped to 50mph and on average they we losing height at 1 metre per second, so gradual you couldn't tell. At times you could feel a gust of wind blow you, or feel a thermal push you up. It was the skill of the pilot to find the thermal, by looking for black clouds or rises from a hill. Daddy had a go on the controls, both steering left and right and controlling the nose pitch. Daddy could see Wycombe, Maidenhead and Stokenchurch quite easily. A house from Grand Designs sunk into the ground was close by as well as the straight stretch of Thames leading to Henley. London could be seen in the distance. Daddy was up in the sky for about 25 minutes before a fast approach to land. Bob skilfully landed the plane smoothly considering the uneven grass field.

Daddy received a certificate for his efforts.

After we all went to the Kings Head in Little Marlow for a meal treated by the Fars. A lovely day all in all.

Captain Gay

Dragged up

Diners

It was James' 40th birthday today. He aimed for a pb in today's Frimley Lodge parkrun, and despite the warm weather, 25 consecutive days running and change in course, James smashed it in a time of 19:43. Rio's in the café afterwards.

Mummy and Jessica went down to Gillingham for Guy's 1st birthday BBQ.

Jessica playing with Guy

Meanwhile Katie went to Emma's 12th birthday do, which involved going to Camberley Cinema to watch Inside Out and a trip to Creams for treats afterwards.

The boys stayed at home making Lego, a catapult and playing 'Wembley'. A board game not played for 25 years or so.

Ben's lego efforts

In the evening we came together again for James' 40th surprise party at Frimley Community Hall..... it was supposed to be a surprise but we all think James knew something was going on. Some of the boys came over which was nice to see.

The Boys

James and Dunc air guitaring

The Elders and Dawg stayed over the night which was lovely.

title.value: James 40th Birthday, Guy's 1st Birthday & Emma's 12th Birthday parties

info.content:
Ben had a half day at school today as he had his first visit to the physiotherapist at Frimley Park Hospital. The session went over the exercises that he has to perform, initially on an hourly basis. They cover knee and ankle exercises. Circulating the foot, bending the knee all in various different body positions, all to strengthen the muscles which have wasted away over the part year. Importantly as well is the way in which he walks. Up till now he has been using the crutches and before that tip toeing on his right leg. He really now has to start putting his heal down flat as he walks in his air boot, assisted with a crutch. The physio lady is going to see us again in just over a week's time, but she did emphasise how important it is to be disciplined at keeping the hourly sessions going. This is something mummy is very good at making sure at.

More interestingly Ben invited some mates over for a sleepover to celebrate the end of term. Oliver, Kieron, Yuvraj, and Freddie came over late afternoon for tea. They played in the paddling pool, had a big Nerf gun fight, played it and football..... which Daddy was not happy about as Ben was goalkeeper playing 'crab' style. Anyway after playing Fifa and Clash of Clans on the computer they settled down and watched the Minions movie at 10pm! Afterward they all began singing various songs in the charts... they all had a good time. Daddy came down to ask the boys to quieten down and go to sleep at midnight! Ben told me he slept at 4am!

Normal Football or Crab?

Watching Minions

title.value: Ben's End Of Year Sleepover & First Physio session

info.content:
Ben's first appointment since his operation.... a big day. Mummy was worried that the problems could be still severe, like a tumour. Ben was worried about the plaster coming off. Daddy worried about getting there on time.... fortunately they got their early and they went by Bus to the BBC, then walked to the Scandi-kitchen for some refreshments.

They made the hospital in good time. First up was removing the back slab which was a bit of an ordeal. The plaster was stuck to Ben good and proper. The plaster that covered the scar / entry point. Water from sachets were poured on to the wound..... eventually, with a few tears it all came off.... then we were told that there was not an air boot small enough to fit Ben. Apparently the smallest they have was a size 5.5. This provided more anxiety for Ben as the alternative was to be a new back slab on and basically the tears were caused because he wouldn't be able to swim in Portugal in two weeks time.

Bandages off

Fortunately 10 minutes later, the 'boot' arrived. A really quick Q and A with the doctor and they were out within the hour. Dinner time!

They travelled back to Waterloo and had Fish and Chips before returning on the 19:09 train back home.

title.value: Ben's Back Up To Bolsover Street

info.content:
In the morning Mummy ran the Sunday school and so was busy preparing activities for her class which went very well.

The weather was a bit inclement..... but fortunately the rain held off for the afternoon as Daddy had invited his Casuals friends over for a BBQ. It's an excuse for once a year to get everyone together, with partners and children. A lovely afternoon. Here was the role call:

  • Steve, Joyce and Eva Barnett.
  • Karen, Richard, Evie and Joshua Sanders
  • Michael, Ellie, Toby, Joey and Lily Elder
  • Martin, Vicky and Owen Aves
  • Barrie West, Julie and Josh
  • Phil and Anna Roe

Some urks

It was a really nice afternoon, some more presents. A bottle of Chateaux Neuf Du Pape, A trip to the darts at Ali Pali and a Danish Dynamite Book.

The afternoon was unfortunately punctured by the brutal rugby tackle of Daddy by all the boys into the paddling pool!!! Rounded off the afternoon nicely.

Dumped in the pool

In the morning Daddy ran his parkrun at Frimley in sweltering 24:05.

Then a mystery tour.... which Daddy loved. Mummy tapped the postcode in the SatNav and Daddy was guessing all the way where we were going. Quite fun. It was quite a long way and we pulled up at Lee Valley Country Park. The picnic hamper came out and lots of lovely foods..... Coronation Chicken rolls, pineapple juice, tropical fruits, all of Daddy's favourites. We made our way to the boat hut, after first taking poor Ben the wrong way for about a mile! While we waited our turn we got ice creams from a nearby van. Then the carnage began.

Picnicers

Ben first at the helm. Useless.... of course he had an answer for everything. It's rubbish.... to be honest I stopped listening so didn't actually take in his excuses. Katie, the same, although more nervous. Daddy we're going to crash! Jessica on the other hand adopted the art of steering the quickest out of the three. We motored into trees and almost other boats, but largely it was a nice relaxing time down the River Lee.

Walking a mile in the wrong direction up the path

Captain Big Pants

The Rabbit in full control

title.value: parkrun, Lee Valley Picnic and River trip

info.content:
The BIG 4-0. Well in some peoples eyes it's a major milestone... for Daddy it's just another birthday, but with a lot more fuss and presents. Katie still thinks Daddy is young.... well younger than many Daddy's of her peer group. Jessica calls Daddy an 'elderly' on the other hand. Ben, like Daddy, doesn't have an opinion - it's just another birthday.

Daddy woke at about 6:15 hearing Mummy and Ben bickering at each other in the kitchen. Mummy went shopping with Ben yesterday, but when Mummy went to pay, she realised that she'd forgotten her purse, so went back later in the evening and didn't get the same items.... which upset Ben!

Daddy was treated to a fruity breakfast prepared by Katie. A decorative assortment of strawberries, raspberries, grapes, blueberries and bananas. Mmm.... then of course followed by croissants. What a treat. Then some present opening. A pair of swimming trunks and some duck, lamb gyros and bacon wrapped pork from Hatto's - He also treated me to a BBQ sausage holder! That boy knows what I like. Katie bought Daddy a 1975 labelled t-shirt from her own money! So sweet and very generous.

Early morning wake up call

Unfortunately Daddy had work.... and had to go in early so he could leave earlier than usual. Daddy responded to many Facebook messages of congratulation. Nice for people just to say hi effectively. Daddy thought it important to reply to each one individually.

At work, Daddy was reluctant for a couple of his colleagues, namely Mia and Anthony to organise a company wide email inviting everyone out to lunch at the Stag.... it was lovely to see, to a man everyone came out and paid for their own lunch.... except Daddy. He was treated. When Daddy arrived at work, his desk was covered by '40' confetti and a '40' badge.

An early exit to scoot back for the evening meal down at the Kingfisher (The Quays). Daddy loves the décor and busyness their. We had the Fars, Susan, Graham, Ma Ma, Pop Pop, Charlotte and the Elders. Susan gave Daddy an Ariel Atom experience day, a T-Shirt saying Established 1975 Frimley and a box of diabetic food. We had a nice, if a bit mad meal.... a cake came out at the end and we all sang Happy Birthday.

The kiddies were in and out constantly..... naughty Uncle Graham dared Joey to throw Jessica's shoe onto the roof, not knowing that he could throw that far.... yep you guessed it, Jessica came crying in with her shoe stuck on the roof, and no return. Uncle Graham felt very guilty!

Atom Present

The Gay's

The Weston's

The kiddies

It's school report time:

Ben's School Report

Jessica's School Report

Katie's School Report

Proud parents!

Daddy ran the second of the Yateley 10km series in a respectable 48:15. He went for a curry after with about 15 other runners. They all sort of sang happy birthday and James got him a wicked card.

Yateley Crew

Daddy came over to Lightwater and collected Katie from her sleepover party and went straight onto Chertsey where they went Kayaking on the tried and tested River Abbey and Thames circular

As it was the height of summer, the plants were fully out to get them. Overgrown in many places. This just added to the adventure and challenge. They started at Chertsey Bridge and quickly went up the rollers at Abbey Chase House which made for a good picture. Now they were deep into the River Abbey. The lilies were out in flower which look lovely.... I'm guessing a farmer has trucked a load of gravel into the river to allow their animals to cross the river safely. However, this made it quite shallow, making Daddy get out and push Katie through some of the tough bits. Other challenges include overgrown plants from the side of the bank, so many lilies we couldn't paddle easily, low bridges and overhanging tree branches. It was all quite fun.

Passing Chertsey Bridge

Abbey Chase House

Lillies of the abbey

So overgrown couldn't see the river ahead

Eventually, they reached the other end of the River Abbey and managed to stop off for a picnic on what seemed an island by Penton Hook Marina. We chatted to a couple of passers by.
