The sun was poking out, the weather was good. The return leg down the Thames was quite quiet. Not many passing boats. We stopped off at swing park in Laleham, and due to Daddy's inpatients they hoicked the kayak out at Chertsey lock and dragged it along the path, missing the lock. They beat the lock!! Katie did really well at paddling, a lot of help this time around. She almost paddled the whole journey.

In the morning Daddy went to a warm parkrun and subsequent trip down the canal café. All good mileage to attain the 1000km for the year.

In the afternoon we had friends come over and join us at the RLC Show. We had the Burrows, Elders and the Morleys. The sun was beating down. It was pretty hot. We drove up and parked as if we were a normal punter..... seems a long time ago since we lived at Dettingen Park, although it is only 18 months since we moved. Anyway, we headed to the rope over the paddling pool, which all the kiddies wanted to go on. Ben unfortunately of course couldn't do it, but was happy to sit on the camp chair we brought and watch. Joey, Joey's friend Dan, Thomas, Katie, Lily and Jessica all had a go. Joey purposely went in the water and got soaked. Next we queued for a long time at the paintball. Everyone put on the camouflage... a little too much. There were items of clothing that had to go in the bin as it didn't come out! Still the kids loved it..... but then Katie realized she had a party to go to shortly and was then desperate to get it off. Of course whatever queen bee does, all others follow. More baby wipes needed!! A go on the assault course and on the fairground and that's about all we had time for. Still a winner of a day out.

All the kiddies on an army lorry

Jessica swimming like a monkey

Camo'ed to the max

Master Guy Morley

Supposedly wiped the camo off!

Katie was driven to Lightwater for her friend also called Katie's 12th birthday party. They had a bouncy castle and paddling pool and 5 friends to play, dress up and sleepover.

Meanwhile back at the ranch, everyone came back for a BBQ. The ribs went down well. I think sausages are getting old hat.... or least last choice. It was nice to see all the kiddies playing nicely with one another and hearing about Jo and Bert's success in adoption. We had a really nice afternoon.

Ben and Lily swapped for the night. A tiring old day.

Katie S birthday

info.content:
Jessica had her sports day which Mummy, Ben and Pop Pop came to watch.

Sprinter

Finally after a year of showing the first symptoms of his leg issue, Ben is finally going to have the operation to get it sorted. Over the past two weeks Ben has been getting more and more anxious about it. How much will it hurt afterwards was the main question. Whilst Daddy stayed at home to get Katie and Jessica to school, Mummy and Ben left at 5:50am heading to Stanmore. The orthopaedic hospital takes patients from all over the south of England. It's the best place to have his leg looked after.

So a reminder of the actual problem. I'm not sure of the technical term. Ben has a malformation of arteries just behind and below the knee. This has resulted in a pool of fluid, be it blood, fat, water meaning that there is pressure on his nerves resulting in him tip-toeing for the past year. Fibrous tissue has been growing as a result further complicating matters.

Mummy and Ben were not long at the hospital before they were called to prepare for the operation which was due shortly. At 8:45 Ben was wheeled into the operating theatre where the main consultant, Mr Pollock greeted him. In all there were 2 consultants, 2 registrars, 2 anaesthetists and 3 or 4 nurses. About 10 health care professionals in all.

Ben was given anaesthetic and put to sleep. The surgeons cut away the fibrous tissue and a slice of muscle, re-routed the veins or arteries and released the fluid. Apparently there will be a 2 inch scare where they entered. A backslab was put on, and loads of bandages. Mummy waited in the chapel and prayed, Daddy arrived from home and joined Mummy.

At 10:45, 2 hours later, Mummy and Daddy were called to the recovery room. As soon as they entered, all they could here were screams and howls of pain. Their fears were realized as they saw Ben in a lot of distress and pain. So much, that his voice was very crackly. The anaesthetist was there along with a nurse. The anaesthetist was trying to get Ben to describe what and where the pain was. Ben was saying that he couldn't move his leg.... and that the cast was digging into him. The anaesthetist said there is not normally this amount of pain. Daddy froze. He was holding Ben's hand, but couldn't speak. He began sweating and the anaesthetist was worried that he'd pass out. Mummy was in a similar state. She had to sit down as she said the room was spinning around. They felt helpless. The anaesthetist was brilliant as he had 3 of us to contend with.... as well as trying to convince a junior member of staff the amount of anaesthetic to inject. Ben was in this very distressed state for 10 minutes until a 'generous' amount morphine, was injected. Ben was still in distress as he slowly fell asleep in the next 5 minutes still complaining about the pain. Mummy and Daddy could breathe again, stand-up and talk. It was hard to take in everything the anaesthetist and one of the surgeons was saying. Basically the operation went to plan. It was hard to say what the medium term effects are going to be. A lot of physio will be required. In the short term, all options are open including going back to re-adjust the backslab or going to HDU. Fortunately he was discharged back to the ward having been asleep for 15 to 30 minutes. Don't really get a sense of time in these situations.

Wheeled out of recovery by the porters

He came around slowly in the ward, fortunately not screaming. Not too comfortable, but at least not in great distress. In the next hour or two, progress was fast and good. It still hurt but Ben managed to crack a smile. We were looked after by the Sister, a physiotherapist came around to give Ben his crutches, which he had been asking for on countless occasions. Eager to get on. Ben didn't like the catheters and drain in him and wanted to get them off soon. He tried eating some bread, but his throat hurt too much and was unable to swallow. This is probably because a fat tube is put down the throat in order to get the airwaves open in theatre. However, he managed some strawberry ice cream and a little later some chocolate. They could take off his catheter as he proved he was not going to be sick. He then could try the crutches out.

Still drowsey coming back from theatre

Well we could see that Ben does not realize how careful he has to be. Over-stretching in his stride and when he came to return to his bed he was prepared to half jump back instead of placing himself right next to the bed.

Early stages of recovery

Monitoring from the nurses became less and less frequent as he recovered well. He even made friends with the boy in the next cubicle and eventually played a two player game of Fifa on the Wii!

Ben settling down to do what he does best

Daddy returned home to pick up Katie from school and Jessica from Paula's house. Daddy treated us to Fish and Chips, whilst Ma Ma and Pop Pop came to visit Ben with a big McDonalds meal and a game of Frustration.

Mummy stayed the night with Ben, moving her bed right next to his and placing her hand on his heart to make sure his breathing was ok. Daddy slept in Ben's bed. Get well soon mate.

Church in the morning followed by a roast chicken lunch.

In the afternoon we went over to Knaphill to Mizens Miniature Railway, one we have not been to before. It was a lot more established than we thought, although not as big as the Cockrow Railway at Chertsey. Still we had a couple of goes going around the circuit.

Choo Choo

In the morning Daddy completed his 118th parkrun in 23:58.

After lunch, we all went to Addlestone to a 'Pick Your Own' fruit. We were hoping to get some strawberries and raspberries. We got our punnets and boy o boy did we find strawberries. There were loads in tip top shape. Daddy was constantly told off by us as he kept eating the fruit before we paid for it! We didn't dare have a sample. Overall we got about £20 worth of strawberries which only took 15 minutes to pick. We also went to get a small amount of blackcurrants and raspberries which still needed another week or two.

We detoured to a garden centre as Mummy wanted to get some plant pots.

At 4:30pm Ben went to Freddy's birthday party..... first going to Frimley Green Rec for a game of football.... then Oliver and Ben were invited to stay for a sleepover.

Pickers

What a peach

title.value: parkrun, Strawberry Picking, Freddie Sleepover Party

info.content:
Mummy turned 39 today. We started with presents in bed. She got a SatNav from Daddy, a swim suit from Ben, a bra from Jessica and Katie.....well we don't know yet as she is still in France.

Opening presents in bed in the morning

We got up at 3am for a 4am coach departure down to Dover. The school were going on an expensive trip to France from Monday to Friday. Destination was La Rochelle. Here is the account from the school Blog

Monday

Through the constant rain we made it onto the ferry to Calais! Germany, here we come (well first France and Belgium). Our journey to France was very smooth, and we are glad to have made it through the rain to the lovely warm evening sun! Everyone is enjoying some evening activities before we go to dinner at the restaurant. Hope you are having as nice an evening as we are!

Tuesday

Today we have been exploring the Parc Futuroscope - a futuristic science park - where we have been on an 'Arthur and the Minimoys' ride, seen the classic French character Le Petit Prince, and discovered even more fantastic rides. Luckily the sun has been out all day, because some of the water rides proved a little too tempting for some! After drying off, we went back to the hotel to have dinner in the restaurant and we are going back to the park this evening for the light show. More pictures below, as well as a video of the 'Dancing with Robots' ride which was terrifying!

Wednesday

Today we have been in La Rochelle, a beautiful port with a famous aquarium. We started the day by exploring the town and having a look round the shops. Everyone had to order their own lunch in French, and then we met up again for the short walk to the aquarium. Inside, we saw all kinds of sea-dwelling creatures, including stingrays, sharks, sawfish and seahorses. Miss Merle treated everyone to an ice cream to finish off the day so we headed home with lots of smiling faces! We are enjoying a quiet evening now, as we have another busy day planned tomorrow. Keep checking back for more updates!

Thursday

Today we have been to Amboise, where we visited the house where Leonardo Da Vinci lived and died, Clos Lucé, and Château Amboise, where the King and Queen of France once lived. We also spent time in the picturesque town of Amboise, where not only did everyone have to buy their own lunch, but we also had a challenge to complete - Miss Merle allocated everyone a budget with the task to find the most unique, most French souvenir. Results to be decided later! At the moment everyone is packing, and we're anticipating a smooth journey home tomorrow. See you then!

Friday

Returning home to meet Mummy, Daddy, Ben and Jessica at Tomlinscote School.

Ben decided that because Daddy liked to get up early, that he would get up even earlier to prepare breakfast in bed. Unfortunately he woke most of the house, so everyone was awake at 6am! A sweet thought nonetheless.

Daddy was treated to Strawberries, milk and a croissant in bed and lots of presents. Again, Ben dropped so many hints about his present. Hope we can share it......... Hope you like it, as I wish I could have it....... I cannot wait for you to get your present...... I think Daddy got the hint that he wouldn't see much of his present. It was a special hairspray that allowed you to get a 'flick' type hairstyle, apparently one that Daddy needs to get, which Ben has already got!!

Father's Day present time

Other presents included a home made pen pot and cushion from Jessica, a mini set of drawers from Katie and some lovely cards. Daddy felt very spoilt by his children!

In the afternoon the crew went over to the Elders for a BBQ . They sat in the sun in the back garden. Lovely.

Katie jumping for joy

We went with mummy for our traditional journey to meet Ma Ma and Pop Pop at the airport from their big holiday. This year we had Auntie Ellie as well. We left in a bit of a rush as Mummy had noted that the plane from Vancouver was 20 minutes early. We rushed down to Gatwick. Jessica said that mummy broke the speed limit! Meanwhile, Daddy received a phone call from Auntie Ellie asking where Mummy was? Daddy said that she left a while a go, but had forgotten her phone. Mmmm.

Gatwick Airport

So we waited and waited, but no sign of the tourists! Then Mummy got chatting to this man. Q. What is the flight number? A. I don't know. Q. Where are they flying from? A. I don't really know. Q. What airline is it with. A. Usually BA or Virgin. Ahhhh. Neither of those airlines use Gatwick. They typically use Heathrow!! Then the penny dropped. So Mummy got to a pay phone and tried ringing Ma Ma, however, the one pound got swallowed before they spoke to one another. Meanwhile at Heathrow, the Elders had left for home, Ma Ma and Pop Pop, not knowing we were at Gatwick hung around for ages. Just what you want at the end of the holiday.... when all you want is to get home! Whoops

In the morning Daddy went to parkrun and ran his 2nd quicket mile, despite starting really slow. For the rest of the day he was constructing flat pack furniture bought from Ikea a couple of weeks ago. A chest of drawers, a dressing table doubling up as a desk and a desk chair for Ben.

Ben and Mummy went to the Frimley C of E school fair. Ben made up a stall, the Beat The Goalie game. He made it up off his own bat - that's some money the school wouldn't have made without him. Proud of him. Mummy helped on the 'Decorate a biscuit' stall.

Katie had a birthday party of one of her friends in Old Pasture Road. She went to the Spectrum to do rock climbing and swimming. Then they went off to Pizza Hut afterwards. She loved it.

Auntie Charlotte came down in the late afternoon and took Jessica along with Lily out to Camberley to try on Bridesmaid dresses. They found some which was a good result. Auntie Charlotte stayed the night.

In the evening Daddy took Farfar out for an early Father's Day treat to the Forresters pub in Bagshot.

title.value: Airport Cockup, parkrun, School Fair, Spectrum Birthday Party, Bridesmaid Shopping

info.content:
It is Father's Day this weekend. As a consequence it was 'Bring Your Daddy Into School Day'. So Jessica took Daddy into school. First an assembly where each class sang to their Dads. There were quite a few Dads who made the effort. Then it was 'Do whatever you like'. So they played ball out the back as well as hula hoop. Then, they cut coloured pieces of paper to make petals on a flower. Playtime next. And they managed to get about 8 kids and dads to join in, in a game of hot potato and donkey. A throwing and catching ball game. After playtime Jessica read half a book to Daddy, then Daddy read the final half. It was lovely to spend time with one another.

Sandringham pupils for the day

Studying hard

Daddy then got a lift from the Fars over to Ascot, where Barrie had invited him for the Westward works do. Bazza was on top form, slightly oiled already. He was worried about the amount of drink (or lack of) that was being consumed. It was a good afternoon, mainly involving watching a race, putting a bet on, going to the toilet, getting the next beer. Repeat this for about 6 races! Daddy won 40p in the penultimate race and got fed up of the favourite always winning, so placed a £5 bet on the final race which came in. As he won, he had to buy Bazza a beer! They stopped by for the singing afterwards which they were not too fussed about. However, a punch up sparked off on the table next to them. Darren jumped into protect the man who just had his tooth knocked out, preventing anymore damage. All a bit of a commotion. As they were walking out of Ascot Daddy notice he didn't have his wallet. Lost £40 cash!

Daddy and Barrie at Royal Ascot

title.value: Daddy into Sandringham School, Royal Ascot

info.content: The pain was too great in Ben's legs to walk. His left leg has been compensating so much for his right, fluid has built up behind his knee causing pain. Mummy got this diagnosed in Frimley Park Hospital A nad E. Ben had the day off school. His operation cannot come soon enough.

We split three ways this weekend. Ben went to a water themed cub camp based at Frimley Lodge Park, Daddy went to parkrun and then run in Endure24. The girls had the Teale's for a sleepover.

Ben went on the Friday to first help setup the tents for camp.

Putting the tents up

On the Saturday, Ben first had Bacon, Beans and toast for breakfast, then walked down to the Quays for some kayaking fun. They played 'family it' with a ball. In the afternoon they took the mini-bus down to Frensham Ponds for some fun in the water. In the evening they had camp fire where they sang songs, ate dinner and played games.

Cubs Kayaking

Ben at Frensham Ponds

On the Sunday, Ben had church parade, then had a water pistol fight back at the ranch. He had a great time overall.

Daddy ran in the Newbury parkrun as a warm-up to the main event which was Endure24. The Frimley Flyers had two mixed teams with 7 in each group. Daddy wasn't feeling the best, but couldn't drop out. What's great is that no one moans about ailments or has excuses. You just get on with it. The weather was muggy. Each lap was 5 miles through a hilly wood, all off-road.

  1. 5km - Parkrun @ 9:05 - 28:01
  2. 8km - Endure 24, 1st Lap: 42:52 @ 1:09pm
  3. 8km - Endure 24, 2nd Lap: 42:52 @ 5:29pm
  4. 8km - Endure 24, 3rd Lap: 45:23 @ 9:53pm
  5. 8km - Endure 24, 4th Lap: 54:18 @ 2:41am
  6. 8km - Endure 24, 4th Lap: 54:53 @ 8:01am

TOTALS:

45km / 28 miles inside 24 hours. Total running time: 4h 28mins 19s.

Camp life at Endure24

Daddy running lap 1

On the last leg, Daddy was desperate for the toilet.... and yes a number 2! Daddy knew there was a stop off area at the 5km marker, but didn't know if there were toilets.... either way a toilet moment was going to happen whatever. Fortunately, there was a toilet.... trap 1 - no toilet paper, trap 2 - no toilet paper, and finally trap 3 no toilet paper. Arrrghh. I had to go whatever, so I did the deed then looked up and saw about 5 sheets left on a roll on a shelf high up. So Daddy got away with it... just.

Overall the experience was good just because there was a great team. Very positive, supportive, friendly and funny. The running; Daddy was disappointed with his own performance, but would still do it again. The weekend's running has tipped Daddy over the 500km mark for the year, so on target for 1000km for the year.

Final team shot

title.value: Water Cub Camp, Endure 24, Teale's Sleepover

info.content:
Ben built dens out of cardboard and bed sheets at the cub hut and stayed over the night.

Ma ma and Pop Pop took Jessica down to the Lydiard Park, Swindon to meet the Greathead's. Jessica remarked how it was lucky Auntie Charlotte was there with some nice food, as she wasn't a fan of Ma Ma and Pop Pop's despite their best intentions!

Daddy spent the day painting the exterior front of the house. We were pleased with the results.

Jessica playing with the Greatheads

title.value: Ben Den Building Cub Camp, Jessica at Lydiard Park, House Painting

info.content: Managed a good run and came in at 49:19. Went down the White Hart after with the Frimley Flyers.

Daddy woke early and had ants in his pants, so went around looking at old haunts in Bournemouth. Yesterday he got a picture outside the Mae Mar hotel.

Went down Granby Road - I couldn't recognize the house we were in..... was it 27? Anyway it brought back memories of the dodgy landlord (forgotten his name) ... the sky dish which Renaud installed... The 2CV which we attached a rope to so Renaud could pull my bike along..... the smashed window.... the electricity meter.... Edmonds. Ah good times..

Then Daddy saw his place in Charminster above the Restaurant - still a restaurant. Looks very similar. Not much has changed in 20 years. Daddy managed to get a pic one outside the Mae-Mar...... he was there 22 years ago!!! Make's him feel old!!

Mae Mar

We went to do Ben's 21st different parkrun down in Eastleigh. However, he really struggled with pain in his legs. Daddy and Ben walked and ran the course and came in at 32 minutes.

Daddy and Ben at Eastleigh parkrun

After, we pushed on down to Charlie's new-ish house in Alma Road, Charminster, a place 500 metres away from where Daddy used to live!

Charlie and Loz had done quite a bit of work on the house and it looked real nice. The Elders soon joined us and we headed down to Bournemouth beach where there was a bike stunt show which was pretty awesome. We played volleyball, football, dug holes and paddled in the sea.

We returned to watch the FA Cup final and had a BBQ, before settling down for an overnight stay. Ben went back home with the Elders.

Katie and Lily

The beach hunk

Daddy motorbiked up to Central London for this year's Bupa 10km. James recommended as the best event of the year. The start line was along the Mall, with Buckingham Palace as a background. 12,000 runners started the race. Daddy set off at an easy pace, but pretty much did negative splits all the way. As he neared the finish he thought he'd put an effort in to go sub 50.... and he did.

Daddy on the start line with 12,000 others

After he met with other runners and went in the obligatory team line-up shot.

When he got home, we rushed him out straight away with us to Farnham Park where we met with Ellie, Joey and Toby for a picnic, a go in the playground and finally a game of cricket and football. Daddy fouled Ben. Ben went off in a grump and it took 20 minutes or so for him to re-join. A great time had by all.

Daddy had another late night, this time fixing Farfars computer who's keyboard stopped working!

Ben's smashing it

Tobot bouncing them in at Jessica

We had a good nights sleep in the hotel which had inter-connecting doors. We went down for our fried breakfast and met with the Fars and Susan and Graham. Straight after we made use of the hotel pool which was great.... and the sauna which Katie had a go in.

We said our goodbyes and headed for Abbotsbury, near Bridport where there was reportedly a good playground and chapel. We parked up in the cricket ground and made our way to the playground. Ben went into one of his awkward moods.... as a result of a late night previously. Daddy made his way up to the Chapel. Couldn't really see Chesil Beach, but there were nice views from the top of the hill.

Funny girl in Abbotsbury Cricket Ground

Jessica with Abbotsbury Chapel on the hill

Mummy drove us home, stopping off at Avon Heath Country Park (St Leonards) on the way home for a little play. Daddy can't last that long these days driving without feeling sleepy.

Daddy had a late night, cleaning a Trojan from the computer, but felt a sense of achievement in completing it.

Frimley Lodge parkrun where over 500 runners congregated. Daddy attempted to shepherd Farah Lily around but died at 4km, and came in at a modest 24:30.

In the afternoon we tackled the murderous traffic and ended up at the harbour in Weymouth where we walked up to Nothe Fort and along the pier. We munched our way through fish and chips on the sea front, before heading to the Riviera Hotel where we had rooms for the night and the location of the wedding party. The hotel was different. It is an art deco inspired building with views across the bay at Weymouth. We met with the Fars and Susan and Graham.

Weymouth Beach

We haven't seen this side of the family ever. Daddy hasn't seen some for 20 years or so. Charlie was Daddy's 1st cousin, 2nd removed.... which is pretty distant in anyone's book or tree. It was hard to get Ben to dress up. He went in his football trainers and a t-shirt. The girls on the other hand more than made up, dolling themselves up. Daddy managed to chat to Jack, Alan and Tina as well as Muriel's next door neighbour, Linda, who still lives at the same house! James was a really nice guy. Couldn't believe how well spoken he was. Very well educated. Daddy spoke to his girlfriend, Iolanda for a bit, discussing our pending holiday to Portugal. There was a fun photo booth where we went in a few times and dressed up in funny hats and made funny faces. I think they were funny faces!

Unfortunately we didn't manage to speak to the happy couple. Daddy was too shy to interrupt the happy couple who were obviously having a lovely wedding day. They did look lovely. A great wedding party.... with a great cheese buffet!

Christopher and Charlotte

The krew on the way to the wedding party

Riviera Hotel

Mummy and Ben on the dance floor

title.value: Charlie Copperthwaite and Christopher Wedding, Weymouth

info.content:
An alright fried breakfast was served by the Bunkhouse. Nick needed to dry off his cycling top as his attempts next to the heater overnight failed. He stepped it up, and tried the oven trick..... but was surprised to see his top smoulder and melt, leaving a massive hole in tshirt and irremovable black 'stuff' stuck to the oven! In the bin.

A chance to take some photos, then they were off again. There was apprehension as to whether they'd make the 26 mile journey in time for 3:15pm when the train left from Lairg. So they quick footed it across following Tutim Burn, stopping occasionally to enjoy the vista.

Route

Loch Borralan and Altnacealgach Bunkhouse

Leaving the Mountains behind, heading East

Daddy and Nick looking over Tutim Burn

Spotting J R Hartley at Rosehall

Uncle Michael overtaking Daddy

They made good time which allowed them to stop for a bit at Rosehall and watch a fly fisherman do his stuff. They didn't see him catch one fish unfortunately, but it didn't really matter. It was a picture. With bags of time to spare they decided to not to take the Lairg road, instead forking off towards Bonar Bridge. At lunch next to the actual Bonar Bridge they contemplated first cycling the 50 miles to Inverness then the 15 miles to Tain. Neither of these options were taken, instead they headed west again to the small village of Culrain.

View from Culrain over the Kyle of Sutherland

The boys had to request for the train to stop at Culrain as it was such a remote station. They were not very impressed when they were charged £7.50 because they got on a later stop!

More poker and two hours later they arrived in Inverness. The four hour wait was soon filled with present buying for the children, a meal in a Chinese restaurant and a shower in the station. Nick went first and certainly was treated like a guinea pig. The shower pumped out scolding hot water out every 20 seconds. The first time this happened he couldn't get out of the water quick enough and cracked his nose on the opposite wall! The design of the shower room also had a flaw in that the water didn't so much go down the drain but was displaced all over the changing room floor, where his change bag was lying. All his clothes got wet! Too top it off he also dropped his cap in the toilet! Jonah.

An unhelpful Caledonian guard didn't defeat the boys getting on to the train with the bikes. They just had second class seats on the way back. Sleeping in two seats was pretty uncomfortable, no one got much sleep. They kept themselves to themselves for most of the journey home.

Day 5, the train arrived at 7:47am, where Farfar was waiting for them to take them home. A great experience had by all.

title.value: Day 4 - Scotland Biking - Altnacealgach to Culrain (60km)

info.content:
The boys awoke to sunshine, and more importantly a scrumptious fried breakfast with possibly the best black pudding ever tasted. Confidence was buoyed by the fact it couldn't be any harder than yesterday. They decided to take the 40 miles easy today, stopping more to enjoy what's around.

Route

Nicholas enjoying breakfast

View from the Old School House

First a retrace of steps back to Rhincoch, then head south along the sweeping roads and gorgeous scenery. A mix of mountains, lochs and coast line accompanied the boys all the way down as far as Kylesku. Fortunately, the weather was fine allowing for some great photos.

Straight roads

Michael enjoying the roads

Daddy setting a new 'sock' trend

The weather chasing Daddy

Nice Scenery

Going down

Daddy's Favourite, Badcall Bay

Daddy enjoying the roads

After Kylesku Bridge started 'the ascent' of the whole trip. A 250 metre climb from sea level.... and you guessed it. The weather conditions turned for the worse. The climb was long, but the wind was not as strong as the previous day. A pair of mountains, Quinag and Spidean Coinich hugged the road as it wound all the way up to the summit. A period of flat before descending to Loch Assynt and a stop off at Ardvreck Castle. This was Nick and Michael's favourite section of the holiday.

Ardvreck Castle provided a physical challenge. A jump across the water to the Castle which sat on an island in the loch. All in all, everyone got a wet foot, although no one seemed to admit it. The boys mucked about in the castle for a bit. Again time was marching on. They had progressed even slower than yesterday! They had 10 miles remaining to reach the bunkhouse at Altnacealgach. The scenery was a little less interesting in comparison with what was seen in the previous 36 hours.

An English couple ran the Bunkhouse in the most remote of locations. They were shown their bunk beds, one each. There was plenty of room, but again there was little radiator space. Daddy had the idea of turning the oven and hobs on and using the kitchen as a Sauna stroke Drying Room! The Roast Pork dinner was a little disappointing. They had a couple of pints and a game of pool before bed.

title.value: Day 3 - Scotland Biking - Kinlochbervie to Altnacealgach (68km)

info.content:
Concerns about the windy conditions were not unfounded as the boys had a tough head wind in prospect. The day started with another superb breakfast. A massive bowl of creamy porridge and toast set the boys bellies off to the best possible start. Lesley had even packed a bacon and egg sarney for each of them. The boys said that they couldn't have asked for anything better from the whole stay. Unfortunately the stay was tarnished at the end, as they were set to cycle off up the hill. Lesley had spotted that Nick had left the Rockets Teapot behind! She quizzed over it's origin. Lesley, a formidable opponent made Nick wilt and he confessed that Caledonian Railways had supplied such a fine piece of kitchenware! The first 200 metres was a mark on how tough the rest of the day was to be. One of the most testing any of them had faced.

Farr Cottage: Nick and Michael suffering from their injuries the night before

Day 2 Route

Michael the Teapot Carrier

Within a mile they had reached the top of Bettyhill, the scene of the BIG crash. The bright sunshine was quickly replaced by a sleet storm which lasted 10 minutes. Daddy stuck on some blue polythene gloves, similar to those found in petrol station forecourts. His hands were absolutely freezing and stung so badly as he raced down Bettyhill. The gloves helped insulate against the wind chill and wet. A lifesaver. Michael had the luxury of plastic bag socks!

The three were soon into one of the biggest hills of the trip, climbing up into no mans land, aka Borgie. The wind was blowing really hard. It was a struggle to go down hills. Tongue was bypassed in favour of a costal shortcut across the Kyle Of Tongue bridge. Again spectacular landscape, with people fly fishing in the estuary. Past the bridge, an even bigger hill, which required a stop at the top and a well deserved egg and bacon sandwich. Only a third of the distance covered, it was going to be a long day. As they were cycling into the wind, they could see the weather ahead of them. Doomsday beckoned.

Kyle Of Tongue Bridge

The skies were grey and thick with rain. What the boys hadn't seen was the hail and increased winds. It felt like someone was throwing ice in your face. The bikes were being blown all over the road which was a shame as they could not take full advantage of the down hills. Both Nick and Michael almost crashed into the side of the road. The 21 miles to Durness sign was passed - no one dared stop. It was a case of getting to any form of shelter. Soon a disused church was found in Eriboll. Daddy went to open the door.... It was like the 64 million dollar question.... there was suspense - drum roll please. Was it going to be open? No, it was locked. Oh dear.

Outside the church in Eriboll

It was a shame that the weather spoilt the views and enjoyment of Loch Eriboll. It is one of the most picturesque scenes with a large expanse of water almost surrounded by mountains and the tiny road. The boys sought refuge in a welcomed tea shop. Shivering through the door, a round of teas and cakes were ordered as they stripped off their wet clothes and sidled up to the heaters to dry out tops, socks and gloves. The weather passed and the troops climbed out of their bunker to hit the north coast run into Durness stopping at some lovely Atlantic scenes. They watched birds dive bombing into the sea to catch fish. Quite amazing.

Beach near Rispond

Rispond Plage

6pm. Durness and a stop for supplies from a shopkeeper who looked surprised that they had to still got a trip into Kinlochbervie. Again conditions were horrendous along the 8 mile up hill stretch, passing Daddy's Kyle of Durness. The strong head wind was joined by a hail storm! They all stopped in the middle of the road, with no shelter, and turned their backs against the horizontal deluge of ice from the sky! Daddy found it tough going. Amazingly earlier in the day, proper athletes ran a marathon along this very route. They must have gone faster than what the boys were achieving. A penguin waddled passed them at one point such were the conditions and speed!

Kyle of Durness

Finally after ten and a half hours on the road, at 8:30pm the Old School House was reached. A modest 60 miles covered in that time. The room was small and basic but clean enough. Team morality was chucked to one side and it was obvious who was after all the radiator real estate! After a quick freshen up, the boys went across to the accompanying restaurant where there was a hen party in full swing! A tough day was rewarded by a nice round of fish and chips and a beer. Daddy and Uncle Michael had to share a double bed!

title.value: Day 2 - Scotland Biking - Farr to Kinlochbervie (98km)

info.content:
Michael had sneaked in during the night and closed Daddy's blind! Opening the blind in the morning, Daddy was treated to remote, snow capped, mountain views and sunshine. What a way to be greeted in the morning. Then Daddy was exposed to a smelly trumpet in the adjoining room! The next station was Aviemore. There was just an hour to eat the Smoked Salmon and Scrambled Egg breakfast and take in the views before getting off at Inverness. The boys had a couple of hours to kill, so a quick look at Trip Advisor and a Bike Café was located and the second breakfast order went in. It was a strange setup. The café had the most limited range of food; toast, cake, Granola or fruit. The bike part of the café constituted a room around the back, where a job interview was taking place. Daddy chuckled as the toilet was right next to the interview - chemical warfare was declared. I wonder how many interviews had been infected with that before? Nick went to buy a much needed jacket which would turn out to be one of his best purchases in a long while.

Route

12:30 and the train rolls into Lairg from Inverness. Finally biking can commence. Today a 49 mile trek northwards. The boys started off confidently, Daddy only wearing the Rockets top. There was a tail wind which made the climb very easy. They were all wondering what the fuss was about. Mountains were seen in the distance. The road was long and reasonably straight, interrupted by the odd cattle grid and speeding motorist. It was a joy to ride. The weather soon turned. A jacket and thick biking top was needed over the Rockets top to stave off the drop in temperature and rain. Thankfully, the Altnaharra Hotel was the boys saviour. A warm chocolate cake and good cup of tea soon perked up the chaps. One cake soon turned into two. The carrot cake was almost as good as the chocolate. Sometimes the thick accent was hard to understand on the friendly and chatty locals, many of whom seemed to have worked south west of London!

Nick and Daddy heading north

A turn to the right at the crossroads and the boys continued north along Loch Naver and the River Naver. Birds of prey were spotted. Claims of it being an eagle were a little dubious. The Loch turned into a river which was followed all the way to the coast. A race to the top of the next hill materialized with a point being awarded to the polkadot champ. About a dozen hills were tackled before reaching the mouth of the river on the north coast. Then Mr King and Mr Elder were in a no holds barred race to the top of Bettyhill. Nick raced ahead. Michael came up on the inside. Sensing the danger, Nick 'closed' the space. Michael forged ahead and try to bulldoze through. Nick slammed the door shut, bolted it and threw away the key. BANG. A clash of metal. Both cyclists ended up in the middle of the road on the floor claiming it was each others fault. It just so happened the only two yobbos in north Scotland were hanging out in the bus shelter absolutely besides themselves with laughter. A chant of 'She fell over' echoed over the crash scene. Daddy was in stitches having a grandstand view 20 metres behind.

Fortunately there was no serious damage. A graze to ones skin, bike and pride was about the sum of it. The toughest two miles of biking was still to come to end the day's riding. First passing an open fish and chip shop without going in was hard, then some proper up hill gradients were experienced out of Bettyhill towards Farr. They arrived about 6:30pm at Farr Cottage and was welcomed by Lesley.

Three hungry boys sat down at the dinner table to the best fish pie ever, consisting of salmon, haddock, cod, hard boiled egg, potato and cheese sauce followed by rhubarb crumble. Lesley was relaying tales of past customers, local MPs help, drug running and the northern lights. An interesting lady. The views over Farr Bay into the distance along the coast line were stunning. The boys were not in the most talkative moods and turned into their bedrooms at 9:30 for a good night's kip.

title.value: Day 1 - Scotland Biking - Lairg to Farr (79km)

info.content:
Seven years ago Daddy went on a motorbike tour around north Scotland and was captured by it's remoteness and beauty and vowed one day to return..... So he did with his Bike and two friends, Michael and Nick. Typically, it was a self managed holiday. The routes and overnight stops all booked up in advance. Hilly terrain and weather conditions will more than make up for the shorter mileage compared with the London to Paris trip. There was nervousness whether they'd all done enough training for the trip.

Thursday, after Michael stopped laughing at Daddy's rack mount, an hour before departure from our house, Jonah rings to say the traffic is terrible and he's going to struggle to make it for the latest leaving time! Before we even start the Jonah strikes. Farfar, the taxi driver, was able to pick him up en-route, through rush-hour traffic to Euston station with bikes strapped to the back of the car. Nick basically spent 4 hours getting from Reading to Euston. As a last minute choice, the boys decided to upgrade to first class sleeping accommodation. They were pushed for time which was made worse by the later than expected arrival and the need to pick up the tickets from an unhelpful man behind the desk. He remarked 'your train is about to leave' as he glanced at his watch. Such an insight to our time pressure was not appreciated as Daddy grabbed the tickets and marched with purpose to Coach J where the bikes were to be stored for the next 11 hours and 500 miles.

Settling into the sleeping compartment, Daddy was relieved they were under way. A tour of the longest train in the world was required, in search for the luxurious 'lounge car' which was advertised on Caledonians website. They walked miles it seemed with no luck. When challenged as to the whereabouts of the car, the barman was dismissive and said that it was different rolling stock to the one currently used. Ahhh. The poorer version the boys were standing in was fully occupied. So there was no choice but to take the beers back to the sleeping compartment and chill. Daddy and Michael's rooms had interconnecting doors, which once opened were open for good, much to Michael's horror when Daddy wanted the blind left open all night! It's like someone shining their full beam headlights into your eyes was the remark. Sleep was hard to come by. Sanity was also slowly slipping away as Daddy became really anxious about the train crashing. He was bracing himself around every corner, thinking they were going on two wheels and over every set of points. What would happen if the wheels did not align properly on the tracks and we left the rails at such high speed? Tiredness fortunately prevailed and broken sleep was attained for the best part of the journey north.

First Class Sleeping Compartment

title.value: Day 0 - Scotland Biking - Train from Euston

info.content:
Daddy went on a final training test run with all the kit.

Oh dear - netting tangled in wheel

We decided to go for a new course today, Thames Valley Park, Reading. I think it's Ben's 20th different parkrun.... and possibly the hardest he's done. He started off quick and his breathing was heavy within the first kilometre. He struggled around with the wind in his face, tears rolling down his eyes in the last 500 metres. His reward was the year's best time of: 27:22.

In the afternoon we went on walk 72, Danebury Hill Fort. Again there was revolt in the camp. It was a lovely sunny, but windy day. We circled the hill fort and had a picnic.

Picnic at the top of Danebury Hill Fort

Happy campers

Old Danish Man

Father and Son

Top of the Fort

In the late afternoon, Nina came over for a sleepover with Katie.

title.value: Reading parkrun, Walk 72 - Danebury Hill Fort, Nina Sleepover

info.content:
We met in Stansted, not too far from Ma Ma and Pop Pops with the Burrows for a charity ride called the Cloisters. Daddy, Katie, Kelly, Thomas, Bert, Jo and Fiona's Dad all embarked on the 13 mile journey. It was lovely and sunny, perfect conditions for a long ride..... The same unfortunately could not be said for Katie's bike, whose rear brakes were rubbing and whose gears only moved in 2 positions. Still she didn't moan, got on with it and did ever so well. A great ride.

Daddy starting off

Meanwhile the rest of us played at the playground and went back to Fiona's parents and played in their back garden.

A nice ride completed in a couple of hours. Next year we all do it!

Katie leading the Cloisters Ride

title.value: Cloisters Bike Ride with the Burrows

info.content:
In the morning we went down to Frimley Park Hospital for the annual fun run. There was a bit of a an organization cock-up, which kind of worked in our favour. It allowed Mummy and Jessica to join Ben in the 2.5km run. Mummy was very proud of herself for completing it. Jessica also did very well. Ben and Jessica each received medals.

Jessica and Ben medal winners

Now it was Daddy's turn. The big 10km, a course he loves and has previously set his PB on. In good running form. Last Thursday he ran a 48 minute 10km, although not sure if it was a one off. He started at a good pace, he didn't look at his watch. James and Chris passed him within 100 metres as did Nick. However, he steadied his pace took Nick and hit the hills at 3 and 5km. Daddy just kept re-iterating 'don't be lazy', 'keep your technique'. By the last 2km he was hanging on a bit struggling to keep under 5min per km pace. He crossed the line in a time of 46:10. A new PB by 90 seconds!

PB splits

Daddy on his way to 46:10

After this triumph, we all met back at home and went straight out for a walk up Beacon Hill near Kingsclere. Katie definitely did not want to do it. It's funny how she deals with it. The rest of us would protest vocally. Katie on the other hand goes into a bit of a mood and wants her own space. She was so sweet as she came and said sorry to Daddy and Mummy separately later in the day. I love that girl so much.

Anyway there was a steep ascent to the top of the very blustery hill fort. We circled and got great views across fields and fields and more fields.

Big Hill Going Up

Beacon Hill views

Katie having her own space

We returned and took Katie to Gravity Force for Hannah's 12th birthday which she enjoyed a lot.

title.value: Frimley Park Hospital Runs, Walk 71 - Beacon Hill Walk, Hannah's 12th Birthday

info.content:
Daddy and Ben met with Auntie Ellie at Alice Holt for the parkrun. It was a new circuit which we failed to complete last time because of Ben's leg. We beat Ellie around which pleased Ben.

We returned home to go straight out to the Surrey Heath show. Both Katie and Jessica were due to help on the Guide's refreshment stall. Katie wasn't really needed as there were many hands behind the shop counter.

Katie helping on the Guides Refreshments Stall

We met lots of people there. It was all quite expensive, but Jessica did have a go on the zorbing park. It is where you get wrapped up in a big ball and you can bash into other zorbs! It was fantastico.

Jessica Zorbing

Later in the afternoon Ben wanted to develop a Man Utd looking search engine. So starting small then..... Daddy obliged and so started back on the basics of a html page and some javascript. Ben seems pretty enthusiastic and wants to keep it going.

title.value: Alice Holt parkrun, Surrey Heath Show, Ben Web Programming

info.content:
We swapped children back over with the Elders. Daddy went with Farfar to pick some horse manure up from a farm to lay in the garden. Benjamin went to Yuvraj's birthday party at Gravity Force (trampolines), then on to the St Georges Day Parade with the cubs.

In the afternoon we went around to Farmors for her birthday party. Susan and Graham were also there. Farfar set up a great treasure hunt. We had frikadeller and lagekage! Rounded off the evening with the dice game.

Farmor opening cards and presents

Hunting for treasure in the backgarden

Creaming the lagekage

Dice Game action

title.value: Farmor Birthday, Yuvraj Birthday, St George's Day Parade

info.content:
parkrun at Frimley this morning with Ben, Daddy, Ellie and Joey. It was Chris Peddle's 100th.

Today Darren came around to do a load of electrical work in the house. We've now got electric to the shed, a light in Jessica's cupboard, a second light in the hall and landing and one in the loft. Cost £330.

The Elders (except Michael) spent the day with us, culminating in Joey and Ben staying at home for a sleepover and Katie and Jessica going in the opposite direction.

Daddy dug a trench from house to shed

Garden digging and church this morning.

We went to pick Ben up from his sixers camp. He loved it. He did pioneering and archery and even washed up.... although he admitted he chose the easy job of rinsing!

Camp fire

Oliver and Ben

We went straight from Cobham to Kingston to go swimming at Kingfisher Leisure centre. It was an odd shaped pool with a wave machine. However, we spent most of the time being chucked around by Daddy. When we got back to the car we got a parking ticket! We stupidly accepted someone else's ticket which didn't last the course of our swim. We could see from the pool the parking inspector plonking on the yellow sticker!

Ben went to Sixers camp over in Cobham with other Surrey Heath cubs for the weekend. He left last night and comes home on Sunday.

Meanwhile Daddy went with Phil, Steve, Nick, Martin and Uncle Richard to Wembley to see Reading v Arsenal in the FA Cup Semi Final. Phil got tickets through his Reading season ticket. Daddy went with the Barnett's from Farnborough Main and started drinking on the train. Rebels! They met with the others at a pub just outside Paddington station.

Daddy sat with Nick and Martin up high behind one of the goals. The cheap seats. The game itself was quite entertaining. It went to extra time with Arsenal running out eventual winners 2-1. There was a bit of trouble near the end where we were sitting. Some Arsenal supporters were sat with us in the Reading end. It would appear some coins were thrown at this family of Arsenal supporters. I have sympathy on both sides. Coins should not be thrown, but there again you shouldn't be provocative and sit in the wrong end with an Arsenal shirt on and cheering for them. You're going to upset people.

Nick, Daddy and Martin at Wembley

The usual lap was done at the end in Wembley. Uncle Dawg told Daddy that they hope to have some news about an impending child. 12 week scan on Tuesday. Daddy made it home at 10:30.

In the afternoon the West's came over for a roast and play some games. The boys and Freya went over to the rec and played football. Daddy and Barrie were showing their old football skills off.... NOT!

One of Katie's new best friend's, Natasha, from Tomlinscote came over to play later in the afternoon. She seemed very nice.

Playing Games

In the afternoon we all went and tried a new swimming pool, Langley. It was in a right dodgy area. Still the leisure centre had a flume, a steam room, a jacuzzi, mats and an inflatable. We all loved it. Daddy spent most of the time trying to shake us off the mats.
All 5 of us ventured down to the church hall for a quiz night in aid of the Guides. We didn't know anyone else there. We were the 'Kooey Banana' team. We came last. The questions were a bit silly.

Jessica on Tiki

After church, Ma Ma, Pop Pop and the Elders came over for an Easter, roast beef lunch, followed by a trip down Frimley Lodge park to meet with the Barnett's. We had to leave early as Ben was not feeling 100% and Katie had hurt her arm playing.

Easter Lunch

In the morning Daddy, Ben, Joey and Ellie did the first ever Bracknell Parkrun. We struggled in at 30 minutes.

Walk 70 took us to Odiham and a walk along the canal to the castle, then across fields, through Odiham itself, finishing the 4 mile walk with Ben being pushed on his bike because his leg hurt.

Jess at Odiham Castle

Ben through a tunnel of hedges

Katie and Lily at Zippos

Pre ride

info.content: As Farfar took Ben to France they kind of compensated with the girls by taking them clothes shopping. They each got new outfits.

Final day. Open the curtains and the weather has finally improved. After breakfast, we headed north again along the front line up to Vimy Ridge. Ben, as were the rest of us, was eager to see some trenches. Vimy Ridge is where Canadians fought and so there was a big memorial, a visitor centre and of course some trenches that had been modified / strengthen with concrete, but the battlefield showed all the scares. It was quite amazing to see all the craters. Absolutely loads. The trenches were not lined up perfectly in a straight line. They seemed to go all over the place. An eye opener to how tangled and disorganised it all seemed. It was the number of craters that really got me.

Vimy Ridge

We continued north and crossed the border in to Belgium. Everything went Dutch it seemed. Language and architecture to a certain extent. Ben was quite chuffed that we were going to be in 3 countries in a day. He thought this was a proud feat to behold.

We parked in Ypres town centre, walked to the museum only to find it was shut on a Monday! We instead went to the Menin Memorial Gate which had 55,000 names inscribed on it, all of whom went missing / couldn't find a body in the Ypres battles. Quite amazing.

Ben decided to enter the Belgian Chocolate shop to get some treats for Mummy. We also went into a burger bar which had a buzzer which you took away with you when you ordered. When the food was ready, the buzzer would buzz for you to go and collect.

Ypres Town Hall

We took the scenic route to Bray Dunes just outside Dunkirk to try and get a sense of the desperate evacuation of troops across to England early in WWII. We stopped walked on the very, big, sandy beach and had another round of patisseries. On the way we went passed Plopsaland, which had transparent swimming flumes. One of the coolest things that Ben has ever seen by his reaction!

Dunkirk

Another Dunkirk

We struggled a bit on the time side, but when you're with Farfar you've always got to rush to get the boat, eh Farfar. Anyway we had 5 minutes to spare, we safely boarded and set sail for England, this time on a clear day. We could see the White Cliffs of Dover.

We finally got home at 8pm, a little tired but a rewarding trip. Ben and Daddy would like to thank Farfar for organising and paying for the trip!

title.value: France - Battlefields Tour - Ypres and Dunkirk

info.content:
The weather really closed in over night. The wind and rain really didn't invite us to step outside, so we had to resort to plan B this morning. But before that we had the embarrassment of breakfast and Ben, or should I say Mr. Fusspot. I don't like this, was the general response. For Daddy and Farfar they curiously had a single fried egg present to them on a plate. Luckily there was a bread basket to accompany this. Strange.

Plan B involved us driving south to Amiens, the nearest city and finding the Piscine Le Nautlus. Farfar decided to sit out this one which was fortunate as Daddy was not allowed to wear his Bermuda type shorts in the swimming pool. So Daddy donned Farfar's parachute which had elasticated laces to tighten around the waste. Phew. Anyway Farfar went to the viewing gallery and read more about the Somme whilst Daddy was attempting to through Ben off the mats for an hour or so.

We ventured around the city to find a patisserie. Daddy thinks they are better than even Danish baker shops. We eventually found one with life up and down the street! We parked up French styley, i.e. just found the nearest half space, and put the order in for a range of cakes and tarts. They were demolished pretty quick!

We crossed the Somme, northward and headed for Albert. Here there was a WWI museum which we ventured into. It was an underground museum with many artefacts found in the local area. Again all very interesting, Ben absorbing the information for about 90 minutes. Ben was desperate to get something from the gift shop, not only for Mummy, Jess and Katie, but also for himself. He was over the moon to get a bag of actual shrapnel from the war.

Fresco in Albert

All indoor events so far, and although the weather was still terrible we were all itching to get out and see where the big battles occurred. We headed to the nearby Thiepval, where there was some heavy fighting and many casualties, especially on the first day of the Battle Of The Somme, July 1st 1916. There are many good accounts on YouTube. Anyway there was another museum and memorial. A modern museum which we rounded. We went to the memorial on top of the hill. It was hard to take the significance of it all, as the wind was absolutely blowing so hard. It started to blow the wreaths off that had been laid many months before. We had to quickly retreat back to the car.

Thiepval memorial

We drove around where the front lines were. All farms. We went passed the first place where tanks were ever used in battle, in 1918. The landscape looked pretty unscathed, we couldn't see mud and trenches, except from one place, the Lochnagar Crater. We visited this. The British tunnelled under no man's land and planted explosives which when detonated could be heard in London it is reported. It made a whacking great hole on July 1st. Quite impressive.

The weather and our stomachs were beating us, so we headed back into Albert, found a restaurant and had dinner. Well sort of. Daddy, ever the adventurous one order a tripe sausage. It was disgusting. The smell was the worst thing, which didn't help eating the rest of the meal. The burger that Ben order was smothered in cheese, which he didn't like. Still he ate most of the rest of it. Farfar had some duck.

Albert Centre

A long day, ended in the room at the B and B. Tonight's football was France V Denmark. We lost 2-0. Daddy again asleep by 8:30!

A jolly boys outing to France. Three generations of Gay's all interested in a bit of war from many different periods. The task was to squeeze in 3 days worth of sight seeing.

We left at 7am and treked our way down to Dover. Ben read his Harry Potter book for most of the way. We stopped at Maidstone for a Costa and a stretch of the legs. Dover was packed out with lorries and many cars. There were over 200 lanes to queue for the ferry. We boarded and left of time.

The journey was a bit roly-poly, but a fried breakfast soon helped settle the stomach. There was a thick fog also, which meant we couldn't see much when we went out on deck. The captain was blowing the horn every 2 minutes, I guess as a way of saying, 'I am here, get out of my way'.

We crossed the busiest shipping lanes in the world unscathed, and we were on French soil. First stop was the 90 minute car journey to Agincourt. The place where we gave the arrogant French a punch on the nose. As we passed through the many villages we all noticed the lack of life. We barely saw a person walking on the pavement, riding a bike or anything really. It was quite eerie. They were ghost towns. Agincourt was a tiny village which had a modern museum in it's centre. Again, we were the only customers in the museum, so had the place to ourselves. Basically the French thought they'd destroy Henry V's army as they returned to England. Aware of this, Henry set a mini trap, funnelling the vast quantities of French infantry and cavalry through the mud which our long bowman exploited. Ben seemed to absorb much of the information. He enjoys learning about things like this. The museum had a miniature scene which helped us visualize the battlefield. It had armour, weapons and some short films which we watched. We were there for about 90 minutes before moving on to circling the battlefield which is now a farmers field.

Agincourt Museum - Armour

The battlefield now just looks like any other field. Amazing to think a famous battle happened on this spot 600 years ago, this October.

Agincourt Battlefield Behind

Agincourt Battlefield Behind - with Daddy

We pushed on and continued south to Mailly Maillet passing countless WWI cemeteries. All of which were in top notch condition. We stopped at one and got out to have a look at some of the headstones, quite moving on how many there were and how young many of them were. Sobering.

Late afternoon and we arrived at our B and B, which was in fact a farm with a number of rooms. We were right at the top. A modest sized room. Ben and Daddy shared the double bed, and Farfar the small bed at the side. We had been picking at food all day long, so we were not particularly hungry. After Daddy thrashed Ben at a number of games of table football, we retired to watch some French TV. Fortunately there was an African international game on. Daddy was asleep by 8:30pm!!!

We had a Talent Show down at the Youth Club.

Katie performing

Jessica sang in her school play.

Jessica's school play

Daddy had entered the Fleet Half Marathon. He had been training harder than ever and hoped to beat his 1:57:07pb. It was an unusually hot, sunny morning which didn't bode well. However, along with many other Frimley Flyers daddy trotted off at his own pace, which he purposely didn't know what that was. He wanted to run as he felt and not to the watch.

After about 2 miles sweat was pouring down and Daddy had a pins and needles, numb type sensation down his left leg which was not a good sign. He persisted on. The crowds down Fleet High Street were amazing. Definitely worth sticking your name on the shirt so people can shout your name. The Sanders crew were there cheering on, so Daddy high fived them as he passed.

After mile 5, the crowds dissipated and the run really began. It was mentally tough. Lee and Duncan, who was struggling, over took me as I walked and took on water. I continued and at mile 8 I was really struggling and couldn't see anything but a jog walk ending. However, the gel I took, kicked in and along with some jelly babies which were handed out, I was back in the land of living and ready to kick on. 1 hour 30 mins at mile 10, and Lee and I were on a mission. We passed loads of people, no one passed us. Daddy thought he had stolen an unassailable lead. However, with 400 metres to go Lee nonchalantly zoomed passed. Daddy didn't think he had anything left in the tank, but from somewhere the boosters came on and he sprinted the final 200 metres. Strava said it was his 2nd quickest 400m time! Crazy. Anyway the final official time was 1:55:53 which was a new pb! Woo Hoo.

The map and stats

We went for a family meal at the Quays. One to remember Ron who had generously left us some money in his will. Two, both Katie and Ben have had some good reports from school, and three we never really celebrated Mummy's GNVQ qualification that she passed.

The decor was good, the food was OK and the service slow. We didn't mind. We had a nice time.

Celebration meal

Made some FIFA posters for the boys to stick in their bedrooms.

Ben

Joey

Thomas

Katie's sleepover friends left about 10-ish, but by then Katie was well into preparing for Come Dine With Me.

Katie had two items to cook for starters: garlic dough balls and a white cob bread, both made from scratch. For main, we had a spaghetti bolognese, again the sauce cooked from scratch. The fars were over and we needed some emergency help from them. Farmor had to rush out and get some onions as naughty mummy had used the one Katie had bought especially the night before. Farmor also bought some daffodils which, unknown to Daddy, she duly cut the ends off and left them on the side. Daddy later picked the ends up thinking they were chive and bunged them in the sauce. Luckily Mummy enquired and we worked out what they were and chucked them out! Pudding again consisted of two items: a chocolate brownie and chocolate nests. All this was to be washed down with Lucozade!

It was a great success and Daddy for one scored Katie very highly.

Katie's come dine with me

We needed to work off what we had just eaten, so picked out walk 69 which was just a mile and a bit long through a village called Whitchurch between Basingstoke and Andover.

Ben and Jess tree huggers

Katie by Whitchurch Fulling Mill

Love birds

Ben and Jessica got on like a house on fire. They wrapped their arm around one another and chatted for most of the way. Ben was saying what jobs Jessica could do when she grows up and how much she could earn! A short, but nice walk around a part of Hampshire that had more thatched roofs then we had ever seen before.

info.content:
Jessica had to go in to school dressed as a Victorian today

Victorian Jessica

£10,000 of the inheritance money winged its way into the stockbrokers pot. Let's get trading. But into what? Well the decision was made to bet against the Euro. The recent 1.1 trillion pumped into quantative easing, making exports more attractive was weakening the currency. Conversely, quantative easing in the US had just finished and an announcement that interest rates are set to rise has meant that bonds are more attractive making the dollar stronger.

So to the trading platform, Barclays Stockbrokers, and first up I am bamboozled by the units, 1,10,25,50,100. Still now I am not sure what they represent, but eventually I plump for going short on the Euro by 100. Immediately I am £300 down just on the spread price. Within minutes that is recovered and things look good. Up a 100, 500, 1000 pounds all quite quickly. In fact by the end of the day I've 'made' £6,500! Not bad for a day's work. The proceeding day also a good one. Up to £12000. Wednesday went nuts. At one point mid-morning I was up £24,000.... In two a half days trading. This was the high point. I think I eventually sold at a profit of £18,0000. Over the next couple of days it ebbed and flowed, fininshing the week on a £10,000 profit.... which in one respect is disappointing looking at what could have been, but on the other hand it is £10000 more than I had the previous week, which you can complain about.

So I have learnt a great deal of lessons over the week. First, it's no good putting in so much money, such that in an hour your profit/loss varies by £7000 in an hour! For one it is not good for the heart, secondly it is too short term as a downward turn can trigger the margin limit and an automatic sell, even though you know it is a temporary blip.

Two, deffo only put in, what you can afford to lose.... I was incredibly lucky and went in at the right moment. If I was looking at a £5000 loss, then what would Laura think. What would Ron think. He worked hard for that money and I just waste it in days. It needs to be respected. It is so easy to fall into a computer game mode, where you don't see the money physically, it's just considered monopoly money.

Gambling and greed, or considered investment and the want to capitalize. A fine line. I questioned myself a lot over the week. How much was enough? Why did I feel quite low, despite getting a healthy profit? Was it right to using this money in this way? Questions I still not sure I know the answer to.

Market downturn why? I am not sure for the past 5 trading days since, the dollar has got stronger. There does not seem to be any news to explain this.... I can understand a 1 day blip, but 5 days? What does the future hold for the currency? The love affair with this is over. Did I invest a bit too long in this because I had nothing else to jump to. Really I need a portfolio of stuff. Don't get emotionally attached. Don't chase.

Euro against the US dollar

Katie and Mummy

info.content:
Two days previous we were told that Ben had to be at the Royal National Orthopaedic Hospital (Stanmore) at 7am for the next round of tests. This time he was going to go under a general anaesthetic and have a biopsy done at the back of his right knee. Having woken at 5am and left at 5:35am we made it in good time. No traffic really. Various staff came around and ask questions, talked through the procedure, all very nice. Mummy was very anxious and could only be involved sometimes. Daddy was there also to help me through.

We had some time to kill so Ben and Daddy went to the Day Room and played some pool. This was Ben's first attempt.... and of course he is as cack-handed as his father. After a bit of practice, Ben was getting the hang of it. We had company and a teenager called Michael played against Ben and Daddy. We got to the end stages and Ben was called in. Some anaesthetic cream was applied and cling-filmed down. At the last minute, we were told to go to the ultra sound department. This sent Mummy into meltdown as this was not the plan. Daddy and Ben saw a senior radiologist who was very nice and examined Ben's leg again. He managed to diagnose the problem in 10 minutes. Why the previous ultra sound didn't show the same issue is another question. The doctors notes say:

  • arteriovenous malformation
  • contains fat and blood vessels
  • no focal mass
  • partially compressible

So main thing he said it was not cancerous. Mummy found us and gave Kumar, the radiologist and big hug. She was so relived. He said we could go home. No biopsy needed.

So, as Ben has mummy and daddy wrapped around his little finger, we went to the new McDonalds in Farnborough which had tablets at every table. Ben had two burgers! Fatty.

It's felt like a massive weight has come off Mummy and the rest of us. Life can continue again. It's been on pause for the past 2 months.

First game of pool

Nurse applying anaesthetic cream

title.value: Ben at Royal National Orthopaedic Hospital (Stanmore)

info.content:
A little over 2 years it has taken Daddy to achieve 100 parkruns. Daddy was touched at the turnout. Mummy even came down. Katie, Ben and Joey ran together. Ellie and Michael ran together, Daddy also bumped into an ex-CNL colleague, Jamie Cox on the run. Farmor provided some very tasty chocolate brownies and Farfar the photography skills. James and Chris had made a cake for Daddy the night before and Maddie made a lovely personalized 100 parkrun fridge magnet.The run itself was pretty average at 23:43. We went to the cafe at the canal centre after.

Starting no. 100

Jamie C, the Elders at the finish

With James and Dunc

We are family

After lunch, we headed down to Southampton for walk 66, Testwood Lakes in Totton, Southampton. We met with the Elders and Auntie Charlotte. It was a soggy walk, which needed Charlie to piggyback Daddy across some water. Us children loved it. It was a long 2 mile walk.

Auntie Charlotte took Jessica down to Bournemouth for the night with Lily. They had fish and chips on the beach.

Meanwhile we took Joey back with us, for a marathon session on Fifa 15 on the Playstation.

Does she fall in? Fortunately No

title.value: Daddy's 100th parkrun, Walk 66: Testwood Lakes, Joey sleepover

info.content: Jessica is now officially a Brownie, having gone for the past 6 months!

Daddy, Katie and Ben went to Basingstoke and met with Auntie Ellie for a cold, hail infected parkrun. Good work Katie especially. Not easy conditions if you are not a regular runner.

Katie finishing 5km

Later in the afternoon we all went down to St Andrews and joined in the quizzes and games.

Party go-ers

title.value: Basingstoke parkrun, Church New Year Party

info.content:
The next stage of Ben's leg saga is to have an ultrasound and meet with the consultant at the Royal National Orthopaedic Hospital, near Regent's Park in London. Daddy and Farfar caught the fast train from Farnborough and met with Pop Pop under the clock at Waterloo.

They caught the bus to the hospital and dodged the leaking ceilings and had an ultra sound. There were a couple of uncomfortable moments when the back of Ben's knee was pressed. However, he remained exceptionally brave. Daddy was very proud. Anyway it would appear the ultrasound has not got us any closer to finding what the actual problem is. We then spoke to a consultant for half an hour. The result was, he could not tell from what we knew what the problem was. He has suggested Ben has a biopsy.

We were 3 hours in there. Ben being a good boy, he was treated to a McDonalds. We eventually made it home at about 9pm! We await the next steps.

title.value: Ben at Royal National Orthopaedic Hospital (Bolsover St)

info.content:
In the morning Daddy completed a busy week of exercise with a 22 mile bike ride with the fellow rockets. There was some good banter flying around.

At lunchtime we went over to Istead Rise, and had a lovely Sunday lunch with Ma Ma and Pop Pop. After we went over to Tiki to sort her out. Unfortunately we could not ride her this week.

In the evening Daddy put back the loft boards the builders had left out!

title.value: Rockets Ride, Ma Ma Pop Pops Sunday lunch

info.content:
In the morning Daddy ran 23:24 in parkrun which he was happy with.

Katie went to Leah's birthday disco at her dad's house. She dolled herself up a lot. However, she did not know anyone there. Daddy came and collected her at 10pm. She getting to be a grown up girl.

Ben had somehow negotiated a sleepover with: Oliver, Joey Harris, Kieron and Yuraj. Not only that, he's managed to get Fifa 15 bought for him. It was certainly very chaotic. Football out the back of the house,Nerf gun fights in the family room at 10pm, but mainly playstation playing. The boys just wouldn't go to bed. In the end Daddy came down at 3am, and went to the fuse box and turned it all off. Ben and the boys had a great time.

Jessica had her haircut yesterday which she initially loved. She couldn't wait for daddy to home, to show it off. For some reason, because someone said she had the same style as a tomboy in her class, there was 'hair meltdown'. Everyone was blamed. She wanted 'hair stentions' (extension), re-styled, the works.

Anyway, it was so bad that she went to school and refused to put her hood down, which the teacher accepted!...... up until lunchtime that is. The teacher commented, we've all had haircuts that we have not liked.

Days later, she has gone back to be happy with it again.

Jessica's New Haircut

The Elders came over. Ellie and Joey joined Daddy parkrunning. Ben's leg restricted him to a spectator today. We held a minute's applause for Graham Petrie.

After lunch, we joined the male section of the Elder family at Farnham Swimming Pool. We were in there for 1 hour 40 minutes! We then went to Alton for a cup of tea and a play.

The Elders stayed over and Joey ran for our first attempt at two lots of 5km's. First up was Rushmoor at 9am. It was cold but we went around in 29 minutes. Ben struggled a bit and his leg was hurting a little bit, but he wanted to continue. We got to Frimley Lodge in good time and decided to go around slowly. Joey ran on, but as we entered the dog field on the first lap a fellow parkrunner, Graham Petrie, collapsed. It was awful. Ben looked away, as daddy stayed to see if he could help. There were a dozen or so of us in the vicinity. Luckily there was a doctor and a nurse. CPR and mouth to mouth were administered. Daddy can remember Graham staring at him lifelessly which was quite haunting. Within 10 minutes the ambulance arrived. It was quite shocking, but luckily Ben was looking away. It was really sad, Graham later passed away.

So although we technically ran 10km, this morning, we had two long breaks. Still it is an achievement. Worrying was Ben's leg.

The Elders stayed for a game of Trivial Pursuit, but alas they left at lunch. We had a good time. Us youngsters were like brothers and sisters. Played so well together.

A Trivial Affair

In the afternoon we were back on the walk trail. We went back to Chatley Heath semaphore tower. Because of Ben's leg we tackled the two miles circuit on bikes. In the middle of the walk there was a tree decorated with Christmas bits which was interesting. It was for charity.

Climbing the hill

Biker Benna

We went home for an early night.

title.value: Walk 65 - Chatley Heath Semaphore Tower - parkrun Double
